TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask him whether, in releasing the report of the McGregor Royal Commission of Inquiry into Matters in Relation to Electoral Redistribution, Queensland in 1978 which led to the sacking of Senator Withers, the Prime Minister, in referring to Ministers who had considered the report, said:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister and his Ministers had available to them the McGregor Royal Commission report and, of course, the background transcript of evidence. No doubt that was studied fully, as one would hope and, indeed, as the transcript in the present meat inquiry was studied. These two cases involve entirely different circumstances. The fact is that one Royal Commissioner found a ground of impropriety and the other Royal Commissioner did not. The situation is entirely different. There are no parallels at all.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, relates to the provision of maintenance by the deserting partner in a marriage breakdown. What procedures are employed within the confines of the Family Law Act to ensure that the deserting partner in a marriage breakdown situation is made to fulfil his or her obligation to provide maintenance for the children of that marriage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to this question perhaps as the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. There are, of course, provisions in the Family Law Act which provide for the recovery of maintenance for the care of children of a marriage. Under that Act both parties to a marriage are liable, according to their means, to contribute to the maintenance of the children of the marriage who have not attained the age of 18 years or, in certain circumstances, even beyond that age where the children are still dependent and reliant for reasons of education or otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: The main considerations for the court in assessing the appropriate contribution of the parties of the marriage towards the maintenance of the children are, first of all, the needs of the children themselves. That is a matter for assessment. The second consideration is the economic capacity of each of the parties and, if appropriate, the children themselves, to satisfy those needs. Once the court has determined the reasonable needs of the child, having made allowance to the extent to which it is proper to require the child to support himself, the court apportions the cost of support between the parties. There are in the Act provisions relating to enforcement. Orders can be made for the payment of arrears, to garnishee, to seize property and so on-the usual methods of enforcement of legal obligations for payment. Also, in some States machinery is provided to assist parties to enforce maintenance orders. In Western Australia this is done through an officer of the Family Court of Australia. In South Australia it is done through the Department for Community Welfare. In other States some assistance is provided by clerks of courts.

The question of maintenance, with other aspects of the Family Law Act, has recently been considered by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. In the main, it could be said that the Committee recommends an increased emphasis on the maintenance of children by parents rather than by the taxpayer. That is a matter which is still being considered by the Government. It is complicated by the fact that the Family Law Act provides that, in assessing maintenance, a court shall take into account the availability of social security payments. That , in a sense, makes it easier for the courts to make lesser demands upon a non- supporting parent than it otherwise might, bearing in mind that the Government will come to the assistance of both the spouse and the children through the social security system. Again, this is an area which needs to be examined. The Attorney and I are certainly looking at it in conjunction, but we have not come to any conclusion or put anything before the Government with respect to it yet.

Perhaps the only other thing that I should mention is that in relation to the recent Budget I indicated that we were proposing to reactivate the requirement that maintenance should be sought in cases in which a spouse seeks from the Government either a widow's pension or supporting parent's benefit; and that there should be some attempt to recover maintenance from the other spouse. I suppose that indicates some movement towards trying to shift at least some of the responsibility back into private hands.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Why was the report of the McGregor Royal Commission of Inquiry into Matters in Relation to Electoral Redistribution, Queensland, which led to the sacking of Senator Withers, publicly released and sent to members of parliament seven days before tabling in the House, while the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, with its grave findings against Mr Nixon, was not released until tabling? Is it a fact that the Minister said, in releasing the McGregor report, that 'it is important that the public have an awareness of the facts'? If so, in the case of the Woodward Royal Commission, why was no such importance attached to making the public aware of the facts when it concerned a matter which involved the maladministration of an industry worth hundreds of millions of dollars, and a grave finding against a National Country Party Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am relying on my memory in this matter-I will have it checked-but my instinct is that the McGregor Royal Commission report was handed to the Government in July, some weeks before the Parliament was to sit. The matter no doubt uppermost in the Prime Minister's mind was that it would be desirable for it to be known to the public. On the other hand, as I understand it, the report of the recent Woodward Royal Commission was made available last Friday. There was, of course, an opportunity to table it because the Parliament was sitting. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister and if there are any further reasons will make further comment concerning them.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the problems experienced by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I ask: Is it a fact that in the early 1970s BHP provided assistance in the building of South Korea's capital-intensive, integrated steel mills at Pohang? Is it also a fact that, despite import tariffs, coal export levies and the 8,000 nautical mile round voyage, these mills, using Australian ore, billets and coal can still produce steel products landed in Australia so much more cheaply that they have to raise their prices artificially by about 15 per cent? Did not BHP management know about 10 years ago what the future competition would be? Does the Minister know what action BHP took to meet that competition, or did BHP simply rely on quota and tariff protection to meet the competition as it arose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has asked a very comprehensive question--
—A good question.

—Yes, it is a good question. It is a very fundamental one for Australia. I say at the outset, because there is a critical note running through the question-properly so-that nevertheless over many decades BHP provided in Australia the cheapest steel in the free world. It is a fact that in the early 1970s BHP assisted South Korea to establish what are now the modern, automated steel mills at Pohang, which use Australian ore, billet and coal. It is also a fact that those integrated steel mills are capital and not labour- intensive and employ a smaller work force to produce comparable quantities of steel products to those produced in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very difficult now to make a comparison because some, including those from the United States of America and elsewhere, allege that South Korea is heavily subsidising its steel exports for one goal-to gain foreign exchange. I have to make that point. It has been said-I have no verification of it-that that subsidisation could be as much as 32 per cent. Various countries provide hidden subsidies to their steel industries. For example, some would say that in Japan the banking system is such that it gives low interest loans to various organisations. If that is so then an answer to Senator Lewis must be tempered by those remarks. I think that BHP must have apprehended that in both Japan and South Korea the development of modern, highly integrated and less labour- intensive steel works would create much greater competition. It is remarkable that iron ore, coal and other materials can be carted 8,000 miles from here, processed and carted back and the product sold competitively. That needs this full analysis. But it is a fact that even if we look at the situation aside from subsidisation, the ratio of tonnes of steel produced per man employed is far better in Korea and Japan than in Australia. So there are fundamental lessons that we have to learn.

There is no doubt in the world that Australian steel works will need to look to modernisation and to much more rapid capitalisation and cannot for- ever lie behind protection, although that protection in terms of import freezing now exists. One of the actions taken by the Government in its last Budget, as Senator Lewis would know, was to arrange for all corporations to be able to combine their trading balances so that loss companies can be associated with profit companies. It would be competent upon BHP to use significant amounts of the profits it makes from oil, and will continue to make from oil, for capitalisation of its steel works. It is a very detailed question. I will put it under study and if there are further facts I will let Senator Lewis have them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the French Government's refusal to divulge health statistics of its Polynesian residents so that they can be included in an internationally sponsored register for the South Pacific. Is the Minister aware that the French Government has not published the causes of death of Polynesians since 1963, or some three years before the first detonation of a nuclear device, and still refuses to do so? Can the Minister confirm that the French Government is not disclosing these statistics because they show an alarming increase in leukemia, brain cancers and other illnesses directly associated with atom bomb tests? Has the Australian Government contacted the French Ambassador for an explanation as to why there is such secrecy surrounding the effects of the bomb tests in the South Pacific, an area of immediate concern to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The French Government is well aware of Australia's firm opposition to its nuclear testing in the South Pacific. The Australian Government has also urged the French Government to be more forthcoming about aspects of its testing program which have been matters of public concern. The Australian Government is making inquiries about the most recent claims which have appeared in the Press. If claims that the tests have directly affected the health of people in the Pacific are correct, the Government would be gravely concerned. The French Government has consistently maintained that its nuclear test program does not endanger health or safety. However, as I say, there have been recent claims which would suggest the contrary view. As I have said, the Government is making inquiries. As we have noted Senator Chipp's direct interest in the matter, I shall see that he is advised as soon as we have further information from the French Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the Minister's statement of last week concerning the Government's decision on drought relief, which is reported to be running at the rate of $70m a month, although the Government is not prepared to make an estimate of the cost involved. Has the Government's attention been drawn to a report that in the last month feed corn prices in the New England district of New South Wales have jumped from about $ 160 per tonne to about $200 to $210 per tonne, while the price of oats has increased from about $65 per tonne to $110 per tonne? Whilst it is said that these increases in prices are the result of supply and demand, I ask the Minister what action the Government is taking to ensure that primary producers, that taxpayers, who are meeting the drought relief bill, and that the Government are not being ripped off in any way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Undoubtedly we have a very severe drought across most of eastern Australia, and we face a situation in which, in most of the pastoral areas in eastern Australia, there are severe shortages of water and fodder and a very considerable need either to destock or to look after the stock by the purchase of feed. In those circumstances there will undoubtedly be pressure on the feed stock market and it is likely that prices will rise. The market in those commodities is not, as far as I am aware, a controlled market. I think that it is not one in which there are monopolies or anti-competitive arrangements which would lead to the ability to raise prices artificially. However, in a situation of much greater than usual demand, it is likely that there will be very considerable pressure on prices.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand the concern which lies behind the honourable senator's question. It is of concern to all of us, and, of course, to the taxpayers of Australia, that the relief measures which are properly being taken to assist this important section of the Australian community should be effective and efficient and should not be the subject of abuse by any other section of the community. I shall therefore take up the matter raised by Senator McClelland with the Minister for Primary Industry, but I believe that only very limited action could be taken to hold down prices, in any sense, when there is genuine competition for available supplies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and is prompted by a recent newspaper report which stated that a newly formed welfare group in New South Wales had strongly criticised the social welfare provisions in last month's Budget. Is the group's reaction to the Budget consistent with any others made known to the Minister in recent weeks? Can he state whether the welfare budget was favourably or unfavourably received by those people who are directly affected?

—I certainly did see a report recently that a group in New South Wales had criticised the Budget. I am not sure how accurate that report is because I have had communications from a number of welfare agencies which have commented to the effect that the published comments have been somewhat different from their total comment on the Budget. For example, the Western Australian Council of Social Service, which was reported to have commented in a critical vein, told me that what had been excluded from the newspaper report were laudatory comments which referred with pleasure to changes brought down in the Budget which had met requests they had put to the Government for improvements in the welfare system. Similarly, I think the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled wrote to me enclosing a copy of a Press release which commented very favourably on a number of initiatives for the disabled and commented rather sadly that that sort of Press release had not attracted any coverage. I can confirm that in fact a number of organisations-the New South Wales Council on the Aging is another-took the trouble to write to me to comment favourably on the changes which had been sought by the welfare community and which were effected in the present Budget-changes such as the shifts in income limits for both pension and fringe benefits. There were expressions of disappointment at the lack of media interest in positive comment. On the other hand, it is unfortunately true that negative comments are more likely to get cover. I suspend judgment as to what the total comment of the New South Wales group on the Budget might have been. It may be that what was reported was partial only.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to my speech of 9 September last relative to the Tehran Embassy and other matters. What action has been taken to investigate the threat made by Mr R. J. Smith, First Assistant Secretary, to Mr D. W. Witheford, as outlined in the latter's letter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs of 8 April 1982? Have any of the relevant files or documents lost by Mr Street's Department been found? Can the Minister provide any information as to what lists might be missing? What stage has the Commonwealth Ombudsman's investigation into the allegations of police bullying of witnesses reached? Can the Minister provide an assurance that income tax has been paid on all government moneys received by Mr Bowden and his children? Why did the Minister for Foreign Affairs seek to have the Parliament believe that the fraudulent conversion of a cheque for $8,700-odd occurred before Mr Bowden arrived at the Hong Kong post? Will the Minister check as to Mr Bowden's date of arrival there and the date the cheque was drawn? Why have not both Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden been suspended from duty?
—Order! I suggest to the honourable senator that this is a very lengthy question. It contains many parts.
—I apologise, Mr President, but it is a matter of some concern to me.
—I do not doubt that but it is the type of question that should be put on the Notice Paper.

—I have only two short parts to go, Mr President. What action has been taken to restore the careers of those staff whom Mr Henderson had withdrawn from the Tehran Embassy at Mr Bowden's request? Does the Minister believe the evidence given by Mr Henderson to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September to be a factual account of the inquiry and other matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, as you said, it is a very lengthy question and there are matters within the question on which I am not advised at present. I would need to refer the whole question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and see what further information can be provided to Senator Primmer.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Drought has long been notorious for the wider distribution of noxious weeds when grain or hay is purchased in one country or State for drought supplementary feeding in another. This week the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry has broadcast a timely warning to farmers who have purchased feed wheat in Hobart since 16 August that they have a good chance of having taken delivery of a noxious weed known as spiny emex. The weed has spiny fruit which cause crippling injury to the hooves of livestock and easily penetrate the soles of boots or tyres. I ask the Minister: In view of the threat this weed poses to the rural industries, what work has been done on its control? If no attempt has been made to import a biological control of spiny emex, will he investigate that possibility?

—It always leads me to have a feeling of envy when a question like this is asked. I envy the long memory that we all have for Jim Webster. There was always a cry for his return whenever matters of a technical nature arose in the Senate. I cannot pretend that I have his extraordinary memory for detail or the ability to get across such difficult matters. Fortunately, I do have some information about the spiny emex; so I am not in a position where I will have to disappoint the Senate by putting the question on the Notice Paper. In fact, the control of weeds is primarily a matter for land owners or local and State governments. The Tasmanian Minister was correct to be warning his charges of the difficulties which can arise when one is purchasing feed or things which will import different plants on to one's property. The Commonwealth has some interest in this through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation . That organisation has carried out investigations on the biological control of spiny emex over a four-year period. The program involved the testing and release of two insect predators but neither was successful. The CSIRO, which is responsible for setting its own priorities, terminated the control program approximately two years ago but I understand the work has been continued by the State authorities in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria. I regret that the CSIRO is not carrying out any research into the biological control of the members of the Opposition. But since the CSIRO is independent, we cannot force it to do that. One can only hope that it turns its attention to those noxious weeds which occupy the benches opposite.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen reports that Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd yesterday announced that it was retrenching 181 employees from its transmission assembly plant at Albury, New South Wales, in addition to 187 job losses through attrition over the past four months? Has the Minister also seen the comments of the New South Wales State Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, Mr Joe Thompson, who said that a major factor in the retrenchments is the Federal Government's export credit facilitation scheme, that these retrenchments are a forerunner to other major retrenchments and that this, coupled with a downturn in all sections of Australia's manufacturing industries, shows a very urgent need for a change in Government policies to ensure that the current employment situation does not become even more chaotic? In view of the disastrous effect these retrenchments will have on the Albury region, will the Government urgently review the situation and hold discussions with Mr Thompson on this matter as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report referred to by the honourable senator. I am not in a position to confirm or deny the reports which he has read in the newspaper. But, of course, I am aware that Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd has been an important component manufacturer, manufacturing both gearboxes and axles. Indeed, I think it is the only manufacturer of those particular components in Australia. The nature of the export credit facilitation scheme introduced by the Government is such that we try to achieve a situation whereby Australian component manufacturers are able to contribute components to vehicles being built both in Australia and overseas. It will be well known to honourable senators, for example, that engines manufactured in Australia have been sent to Europe for inclusion in cars being built on that continent and that other components being made in Australia are being sent overseas. It is important to achieve economies of scale and for Australia to be part of what is more and more a world car market.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular effect of that policy on Borg-Warner is a matter which was the subject of considerable representation to all honourable senators at the time the car policy was before the Parliament. I think that company expressed concern that the components which it manufactures would be likely to be replaced by components manufactured in other parts of the world. I understand that that company is an important industry in Albury and that it is an important employer. I will ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce to give me more detailed advice on the various matters which have been raised by the honourable senator in his question. But it remains true that any policy which involves Australia taking its place in what is essentially now a world industry will almost inevitably involve trade-offs between one part of the industry and another. It is unlikely that any policy pursued by the Government would result in all areas of the Australian industry maintaining exactly the same state of health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that 368 people in the Albury district have lost their jobs in this one plant in four months, will the Minister answer the second part of my question, that is: Will the Government hold discussions on this matter with Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union?
—I will refer that part of the question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce for his consideration.

—I ask the Minister for Education: Is it true that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission funded report evaluating student services in tertiary education in Australia has now been completed? Does the report refer to the effects of changes in the general economic climate, leading to more students being in need and more calls being made on student assistance, including emergency loan services? Will the Budget announced increases in the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the Commonwealth post-graduate award bring substantial remedy to student needs as described in the report? Is the report evidence that the student loan scheme proposed by the Government would be so welcomed by tertiary students that the amount of $50m to be involved for 1983 is likely to be fully taken up? Finally, does the report urge individual institutions, especially in the colleges of advanced education and the technical and further education sectors, to take more responsibility for the development of student services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the Budget provided real advances for students throughout Australia and that student assistance, by way of tertiary allowances and also, of course, assistance to students in secondary education, was considerable. People seem to have forgotten in some of the debates that take place that there was a 20 per cent increase in the level of the TEAS allowance announced in the Budget; that there was an extension in the means test; that for secondary students there was an extension of 40 per cent in the means test; that for tertiary students there was an increase of almost 50 per cent in the post- graduate allowance. There is no doubt that the Government has moved very definitely to assist students and to respond in this Budget to what are students ' needs for assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed loan scheme to which Senator Teague referred in his question is, of course, an extra option for students. It would enable those students who wished to do so to take out another form of support to get them through the period of their tertiary education. It is the Government's intention that this should happen. I should like to take on notice the question in relation to the report mentioned by Senator Teague, because of some uncertainty about the exact details he requested. But insofar as his questions about the report were designed to put into context the issues related to the Government's support for students, I can give him the assurances he seeks and can say to him that the Government's contribution through this Budget has been considerable and has been sympathetic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and follows closely on Senator Martin's question, directed to the Minister for Social Security yesterday, relating to the recognition of de facto relationships. My question relates to health insurance when a de facto partner pays family rates, even though there are no children involved, which she or he then claims for taxation purposes. I ask: Is the Minister aware that this type of claim is not being allowed, at least not by the Australian Taxation Office in Perth? In a recent communication from that Office, one of my constituents was informed:

QUESTION.PARA: The basic health insurance rebate applies only to premiums which secure entitlement to basic benefits for the taxpayer on his/her legally married spouse .

Will the Minister advise when we can expect amending legislation to remove such phrases as 'legally married spouse' from the Income Tax Assessment Act, thereby avoiding the current confusion which exists in other legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of any proposed changes to legislation that would encompass the matter that has been raised by Senator Coleman. If there is any particular difficulty in the question that needs reference to the Treasurer I will see that that is done. In general terms, I am not aware of any proposed changes that would be forthcoming, for instance in this session of parliament.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the announcement the Prime Minister made yesterday of a review of the Commonwealth Public Service. I believe that most public servants will welcome such a review as, although there may be a few who are no credit to the Public Service, the majority are conscientious and dedicated. Will the Minister give an assurance that the review will have regard to the need for the Public Service to remain apolitical and impartial? Can we ask that the review give consideration to the means of establishing some appropriate mechanism to allow public servants, irrespective of status, to report apparent waste, inefficiency or inaction without fear of placing their career prospects in jeopardy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is an important one. I share with Senator Reid the high regard for the great majority of public servants who I believe serve this community with skill and dedication. I can give an assurance that fundamentally the Government's aim is that the Public Service will be entirely apolitical and impartial-that will be beyond doubt-and that the environment will be such that public servants can give of their best. I will bring the latter part of Senator Reid's question to the attention of the Prime Minister and see whether in fact in the present terms of reference it is encompassed or whether it can be so encompassed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Would the Minister agree that one of the principal tasks of the Attorney-General is to promote respect for the law? Does he consider, therefore, that despite his disclaimers the Prime Minister's disparaging public remarks concerning Mr Justice Woodward's perception and judgment diminishes in the eyes of ordinary Australians respect for the law and for those responsible for its administration? If he does give credence to that position, what has the Attorney-General done, as principal law officer in the land, to retrieve the situation? If he does not consider that the Prime Minister 's public disparaging remarks in respect of a senior judge have not diminished respect for the law in the eyes of the people, would he not agree that perhaps this is because the ordinary people have more respect for judges than politicians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all may I indicate very clearly to the Senate and to the honourable senator who asked me the question my absolute and unbounded respect for the judge referred to. I think Mr Justice Woodward has served Australia in a number of capacities with very great distinction and I would think that no one in the Government, from the Prime Minister down, would wish to say anything which would be taken to be disparaging of him. I would say that any such interpretation would not be the interpretation that was intended by the Prime Minister or by anybody else.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, with regard to promoting respect for the law, may I say that we are here talking about a report which has been brought down by a royal commission. It is one of many reports of royal commissions which have been received by this and other governments over the years. I would suggest that no honourable senator, on reflection, would deny himself or herself the right to differ with any particular finding of a royal commission. If I may take a quick example, I am sure that if Senator Harradine were given the report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships he would immediately enter a violent objection to many of the views and recommendations which are set out in that report. I do not necessarily embrace that-

TALK.START.PARA: —But not on findings of fact.

—Including on findings of fact. I think it would be true that that would be so. As far as the matter of finding facts in this or in any case is concerned, I would certainly reserve my position and the right to examine the matter and to decide whether I disagreed or agreed with the findings. Royal commission reports can be of great assistance to the Australian people and to the Government. It is true, however, that royal commission reports do not have the quality of being written on tablets of stone. I do not believe that anybody bringing down a royal commission report would claim qualities of infallibility. It remains open to the Government or indeed to anybody else to question findings if they wish. I wish to point out that I would not want anything I say ever to be interpreted as being in any way disparaging of one of the Australians I most admire.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTRICITY CHARGES IN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to the extent of increases in electricity prices in New South Wales for industrial and commercial consumers during 1982? Can the Minister indicate how prices for industrial and commercial consumers in Sydney compare with those in other capital cities? Is the Minister concerned at the damaging effects upon industrial and commercial users' costs, the likely loss of jobs and the likelihood that industry and commerce will be driven out of New South Wales? Does the Minister agree that the Wran socialist Government, due to its maladministration, clearly is responsible for these sudden steep electricity charges? How does the Minister view the reality of the New South Wales power crisis with the Wran Government's past promises of abundant cheap power in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lajovic has asked a very long question with some five aspects to it. I am, of course, very well aware of the situation in New South Wales where in fact there have been enormous increases in the prices of electricity for domestic, commercial and industrial purposes. I think everybody is aware that despite the fact that there is excess installed capacity for electricity there has been an incapacity of the Government concerned over the years to maintain that installed capacity. The effect has been that enormous costs have been incurred. I saw an estimate the other day-I do not know how accurate it was-which showed that the costs to the Liddell power station alone for repairs will be of the order of $140m. I am unable to substantiate that figure but it is something of that magnitude. I was asked about this in terms of Mr Wran's promises. At his election one year ago he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we have embarked upon the biggest power generation program in the history of Australia. We are determined that the needs of industry shall be met. We are equally determined to protect the householders, the ordinary domestic consumers of electricity. New South Wales has the cheapest electricity to householders in Australia. We are going to keep it that way.

That was his election promise. The reality is that in Sydney consumers face the most expensive electricity in Australia. For example, by July 1982 the average prices of electricity for small and medium scale industrial or commercial users respectively were 7.74c per kilowatt hour, an increase of 87 per cent since July of last year, and 6.75c per kilowatt hour, an increase of 100 per cent since July of last year. An even more graphic example of the failure of the Wran promise is evident from a recent published report by NUS International Pty Ltd which compares electricity prices in various capital cities throughout the world for large, medium and small scale industrial consumers. The table shows that Sydney was assessed as now having, in general, the highest electricity charges of all those cities surveyed. Clearly, of course, that is an outrageous situation in terms of the promises made by Mr Wran.

An example of the direct effects of these electricity tariff increases on a Sydney company is contained in information which it recently provided to me. This is the result: An increase in the tariff from 1.84c per kilowatt hour in December of last year to 4.8168c in August of this year, an overall increase of 162 per cent for the period, which leads to an additional annual cost of $300, 000 to that company and to the very real prospect of the loss of the 180 jobs involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table the letter.
—I would be very happy to table the letter in the Senate and I will do so tomorrow.
—After you have doctored it. You have done that before.

—The fact is that the Wran Government indicated to the people of New South Wales that it had an excess capacity of electricity, that it was the cheapest and that it could take on more industries. In fact it is incapable now--
—Make sure the ink is dry when you bring it in.

—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that interjection. There was an implication there about making sure the ink was dry when the Minister said he would table the letter tomorrow. The Minister stated that he had the letter and you implied that the letter would be fresh from his hands and that the ink had better be dry. I ask you for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal.
—I ask that all of the pages in the document from which the Minister quoted be tabled, not only one.
—Order! Senator McLaren, will you wait a moment, please?
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I intend not only to table the letter but also, with the indulgence of the Senate, to read it into Hansard as soon as it is provided to me. The fact is that the Wran Government said to the electors: 'Elect us. We have an excess capacity of electricity. It is the cheapest in Australia. We can provide for more industries and we will continue to be the cheapest in Australia .' That was a total failure. Now commercial and industrial electricity is not only the dearest in Australia but also the dearest of those cities around the world which were surveyed. I was asked to table the notes from which I quoted, and I do so.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether, in view of the Government's decision not to refer the 1982-83 Budget Estimates to the House of Representatives Estimates committees for the usual scrutiny, he will advise whether this will lead to a concentration of power in the Executive. Will this not mean that the people of Australia will have to place increased reliance on the review procedures of the Senate and its committees? Can we have an assurance from the Government that it will place greater reliance on the Senate's power of review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has been only in recent years that Estimates committees have functioned in the House of Representatives. It was an innovation , I think, of the Fraser Government. I may be wrong on that. In the past that facility was not available. There is always the opportunity to deal with the appropriations on the floor of the House of Representatives. I see no diminution in that and I see no increase in the Executive power. During the time of this Government the explanatory notes on Estimates have become increasingly fuller and, indeed, the information has been more forthcoming to honourable senators. Of course the explanatory notes are available to members of the House of Representatives. The Government has always invited the closest scrutiny of the Budget and will continue to do so. The honourable senator asked whether the Government would do anything to increase the powers of the Senate as a house of review. This Government is pledged to that; it is pledged to the development of a complete review. That is how we work in this place. We work through committee systems, we exercise a thorough scrutiny and we put no obstacles in the way of that.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: How can he have the gall to answer the previous question in the way that he did? Will he accept responsibility, as Leader of the Government in the Senate and as a senior member of the Government, for boasting of a resources boom of great extent which subsequently failed and led to an increase in unemployment in Australia? How can he justify his answer and his attack on Neville Wran in New South Wales when he was the architect of the greatest economic failure that this country has faced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not be more grateful to the honourable senator for his question. In fact, this Government said that the size of the investment in resources in the whole of Australia would be $31 billion. Concurrently, Mr Wran said that, of that amount, $23 billion would be invested in New South Wales . DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The rapidly declining standards of government administration.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every week Sir James Killen, the Minister for doing nothing as he is sometimes called, is asked in a question upon notice what he has done during the past week. He always answers by saying: 'I have administered my Department'. In his case, but in no other ministry in this Government, it is probably true, because he has only five people to administer. He probably does that reasonably well. One of the functions which the Constitution lays down for Ministers is quite simple; it is to administer departments. That provision is contained in section 64 of the Constitution. What we have with the Fraser Government is that, instead of administering departments, many Ministers have indulged themselves with private activities outside the sphere of government or developed to the point of irresistible genius the new doctrines of the Fraser Government of malpractice and maladministration. These new doctrines which have developed in the last few weeks compare quite starkly with the remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his electoral talk on 12 March 1978 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government. As long as I lead the Government, there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

I ask honourable senators to remember that statement by the Prime Minister as one looks at the record. What the Fraser Government is confronted with in 1982 is a sort of latter-day equivalent of the rum rebellion. Tax evaders, dishonest doctors and subversives in the ranks of the Liberal Party cry out against honest administration. Privileged groups in the community advance their personal interests at the expense of the revenue of this country. The only difference from the rum rebellion is that the Prime Minister, unlike Governor Bligh, has not yet been caught hiding under the bed. Instead he has been caught hiding in a web of deceit, changing standards and words, words, words about his Government similar to the words which I quoted a minute or two ago.

By way of illustration, let us look briefly at what has happened since this Government came to office. I do so by mentioning only some few of the 22 Ministers who have fallen from grace since Malcolm Fraser was elected as Prime Minister of this country. First of all, in 1975 there was Sir Victor Garland on a charge of bribing an elector. Subsequently, he was restored to the Ministry, sent overseas, knighted and later discovered to have been involved in tax evasion schemes on a significant scale. Next there was Mr John McLeay, a former Minister in the Government. He was sent overseas. He is now the subject of a civil action in South Australia, by the liquidator of a company, alleging fraud and misappropriation. Presumably he will come back to defend that action. Thirdly, we have the former Senator Webster. He was sent overseas, having been saved by the then Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Garfield Barwick, from being subjected to the full benefits of the provisions of the Constitution relating to pecuniary interests. Mr MacKellar, dismissed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think that is a reflection on the High Court of Australia and upon the judiciary. As I understand it, the words were that he had been saved by the Chief Justice from the full effects of the Constitution. That is a reflection upon any member of the High Court and certainly it is offensive.
—I think Senator Button might rephrase that sentence to imply that the effect of the decision was that nothing of consequence happened. He should use some such appropriate rewording.
—As a result of a decision by the Chief Justice, nothing of consequence happened to former Senator Webster other than him being sent overseas, if I can put it in those terms.
—But he was exonerated, wasn't he?
—He was exonerated, Senator Jessop, by a decision that no respectable lawyer in this country would regard as believable in terms of the circumstances in which it was given.
—I think, Senator Button, that you are continuing to say what was ruled out of order. You should make it quite clear that former Senator Webster was exonerated by the Court.

—Senator Webster was exonerated by Sir Garfield Barwick. The next Minister to whom I wish to refer, going down the pecking order, is Mr MacKellar who was dismissed by the Prime Minister for petty smuggling. Mr Moore was dismissed by the Prime Minister for being an accessory after the fact to petty smuggling. Senator Withers was dismissed for impropriety, of all things, which stands out as the insect compared with all of these offences that I have listed. Mr Peacock resigned on the basis that he said that the Prime Minister had cast aside the stability and sense of direction of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Then, of course, we have the next group of Ministers, the great survivors. Sir Phillip Lynch was removed as Treasurer because of his involvement in land dealings. He was subsequently restored to the Ministry, but not as Treasurer. We have Senator Durack, the Attorney-General and Mr Howard, the present Treasurer, who presided over vast tax evasion and loss of revenue to this country. Mr Sinclair, believed by a jury after six hours' deliberation as to whether it would believe him or not and disbelieved by a Senate committee, stood down from the Ministry and was subsequently restored. He and his colleague, Mr Nixon, presided over the Asia Dairy Industries scandal and the meat malpractice scandal of recent fame. We have Mr Hunt, who presided over the medifraud developments of the last few years. But the point I wish to make is that never in the history of this Government since 1975 has there been a time when there was not a Minister who was free from the taint of corruption and incompetence.

This Government has been responsible for the loss of billions of dollars of revenue through tax avoidance. It has been responsible for the jeopardising of Australia's billion dollar meat industry. It has been responsible for massive scandals in relation to medifraud. It has been responsible for the Asia Dairy Industries scandal in which $3m just disappeared into an unmarked Singapore bank account and it has been responsible for all the petty misdemeanours, such as smuggling television sets. The Australian economy is currently in the worst mess it has ever been in. The country is facing enormous problems and what it needs, before any of those problems can be tackled, is honest, credible government, not grand deceits on the scale practised by the Fraser Ministry. There is no hope of restoring the credibility of this Government. It has had more Ministers acquitted than it has ever had tax evaders convicted. Its only hope at the next election is perhaps to seek to persuade the people that this time it will lead a tax evasion led recovery. That is the only hope this Government has because all of its other ploys have been exhausted. We even find the Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) visiting a convicted criminal in gaol, presumably to find out about the state of the food. These are the extraordinary things which go on in connection with this Government. The whole problem arises, of course, because it has no standards and it has had no standards since its beginning. It has no standards of ministerial responsibility, it has no standards of accountability of Ministers and it has no standards of accepting any responsibility at all for the proper government of this country. I want to illustrate those points.

Let me deal first of all with the question of standards of ministerial responsibility. What we have seen here is a continual change in the standards of ministerial responsibility to fix every particular case which arises. In 1972 the present Prime Minister laid down the sort of standard which he thought would be appropriate to a government led by him. He said that the standard was that if a blunder of any real importance to Australia occurred in a department, even if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should take the responsibility and resign. That was the 1972 Fraser standard. In 1976, the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration reported to the Government. The Coombs Royal Commission laid down the standard of ministerial responsibility as being that unless the action which stood condemned was the Minister's action or was taken on his or her direction or was action which the Minister ought obviously to have been concerned with, the Minister should not resign. In 1978, the Prime Minister again laid down a new standard which I have already quoted, the new standard to which I referred at the beginning of my speech, in which he said that the highest standards of integrity and code of practice would be observed. In 1982 the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, said that the standard now applying to Ministers, and in this case he meant him, was that a Minister should not resign unless there was personal fault. In 1982, two weeks later, the Prime Minister, in relation to Mr Nixon, abandons that standard set by Senator Durack in rejecting the finding of a distinguished Royal Commissioner who found personal fault in a Minister. The Prime Minister said that that standard no longer applied. A few years earlier when Senator Withers was dismissed, the Prime Minister said that the Government had no option but to accept the finding of a royal commission. This week, when it came to a National Country Party Minister, Mr Nixon, all the options were available.

The question that arises in respect of these matters of honesty and propriety as far as the Fraser Government is concerned is: Who guards the guardians in Australia now? If a royal commissioner of the calibre of Mr Justice Woodward is not accepted as an authority on what is proper ministerial behaviour, where are the checks and balances now? Who determines whether a Minister has behaved properly? A royal commission is not good enough any more. How can any public service be administered by a Ministry which is subject to these sorts of rafferty rules? A system has been set up by the Prime Minister to determine whether a Minister has company shareholdings and directorships from which conflict of interest arises with his duty as a Minister. In the Fraser Government that is a matter that the Prime Minister decides. He alone makes that decision. There is no public information as to what directorships and shareholdings Ministers hold. All of those matters are reported to the Prime Minister and he alone decides whether there is a conflict of interest with the Minister's duty. That is a cowardly sort of standard for a government to have. It is the sort of standard which has led to the present disarray.

The first defence to these charges of the present Government is to keep changing its standards on all of these matters, lowering its standards. The second defence is that somebody else is always to blame. The scapegoat syndrome has been the characteristic of this Government right from the beginning. More recently the Australian Public Service has been added to the list of scapegoats for ministerial failures and irresponsibility. Look at the massive tax evasion racket revealed in the last few weeks consequent upon the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. As a result of that three minor public servants in Perth have been charged with offences under the Public Service Act. The Crown Solicitor in Canberra is investigating himself to see whether his conduct was good enough. The Ministers responsible-the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack)-have resiled from any responsibility at all. Inadequacies in respect of medifraud are blamed on the Public Service and not the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). Inadequacies in respect of the meat scandal are blamed on the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry for finding the wrong facts and on public servants. Public servants again are blamed in respect of the Asia Dairy Industries scandal. The Prime Minister's latest effort is to announce an inquiry into the Public Service, if you please, to try to straighten out some of these things. The Prime Minister, in a statement made on the kerbside yesterday morning, foreshadowed a major examination to see that administrative breakdowns do not occur. He asked Ministers to give him a full and complete report on all aspects of their own administration and to give that report within a week. We hear the Prime Minister going on with that sort of gobbledegook when two and a half years ago the Williams Royal Commission into Drugs told this Government that it should do something to tighten up regulations on container cargo containing drugs which was coming into Australia. Nothing has happened two and a half years later in relation to drug importation into this country.

When we look at the statements which have been made by the Prime Minister about integrity in Government and the Public Service and we look at the decision of April 1981 of the razor gang and all the windy rhetoric which accompanied that, we see how paralysed this Government is in doing anything in terms of administration. In April 1981 the Prime Minister said very pompously:
We intend to establish major reviews into a number of significant areas of Commonwealth activity in order to further tighten administration and achieve a more efficient and effective service.

What has happened to that for goodness sake? We do not hear much about that any more. He set up a committee of senior Ministers to rein in the growth of government-it has expanded ever since-and to ensure that there was positive progress. What happened to them, or was that mere rhetoric of April 1981? What has been revealed in September 1982 is that in fact nothing has been done by Ministers.

If Australia is to have a good Public Service of integrity and impartiality, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate implied at Question Time today, it must have trust in the people who are entrusted by the Constitution to administer it-that is, the Ministers of this Government-and it must respect them . There is no reason why the Public Service should respect Ministers in this Government any more than anyone else does in this country after what has been revealed. Of course, to say it is a matter in which responsibility lies down the line is just ridiculous. Honourable senators need not take my word for it but can take the words of Mr Peacock, a former Minister, who in resigning from the Fraser Government said this:
I believe you-
The Prime Minister--
have cast aside the stability and sense of direction of the Government.
He went on to say:

Over recent months I have regretfully concluded that the Prime Minister is fracturing Cabinet government and the parliamentary system as we know it. Our system of government will operate only if there is a responsible relationship between the Cabinet and the Parliament. Our present system has deteriorated because that relationship has foundered. It has foundered because the Prime Minister increasingly centralised power around himself. Any erosion of the Cabinet system goes to the heart of the parliamentary process. By reposing too much power in the Prime Minister, the system of collective responsibility within the Cabinet is destroyed; the responsibility of Cabinet to Parliament is abandoned; and the very democratic process is placed in jeopardy.

They are not my words. Mr Peacock knows why the Public Service in Australia is being blamed for all these things. He knows why the Public Service in Australia no longer looks to this Government and expects honest, sensible, well- administered decision making from Ministers. All I can say is that this stems right back to the Prime Minister. In the words of Mr Peacock's statement, because the Prime Minister has too much power, the system of collective responsibility has been abandoned. It is not abandoned as far as we are concerned. Ministers collectively are responsible for what has happened in this country, for the current state of the economy and for the disrespect in which the Government is held. We will continue to hold them collectively responsible until the next general election, when the people of Australia will do so too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a remarkable speech from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, who seems to be under the illusion that we are debating a resolution. We are in fact debating a matter of public importance put down by my colleague, Senator Button, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The rapidly declining standards of government administration.

In the first 15 minutes of Senator Sir John Carrick's speech we heard his account of the history of the Whitlam Government and his complaint that Senator Button had the audacity to draw to the attention of the Senate some of the problems which have faced the present Government and some of its Ministers. He then demonstrated how consistent he was in his complaints about Senator Button's actions by casting aspersions on a judge of the High Court of Australia-a former Attorney-General in this place and a man who, in fact, will be the second senior High Court judge.

I think it is worth while drawing to the attention of the Senate that Senator Sir John Carrick has to behave the way he does. He behaves in this way because, first of all, he has no defence against the matter brought up by Senator Button, and secondly, he is bound to defend his Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Senator Sir John Carrick is bound to defend his Prime Minister because, unlike anyone on this side of the House, he is not an elected Leader of the Government in the Senate; he is the chosen one of the Prime Minister. He would not be in that position if he had to be elected. He would be sitting somewhere near where Senator Withers is sitting now. The simple fact of the matter is that he depends on the Prime Minister of the day for his position, his power and his authority. I certainly do not envy his being in the hands of a gentleman like that.

Senator Button has raised this matter of the declining standards of government administration because anyone who reads the newspapers, who looks at television or who has attended or taken any notice of what has been happening in this Parliament in the last few months cannot help being concerned with the rapidly declining standards of government administration. We judge the present Government on what were said to be its standards, the sorts of standards which were espoused by Malcolm Fraser, the Prime Minister, in 1978, when he said:

Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no Government can hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people . . . As long as I lead the Government there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

Day by day, more and more information comes out about dishonesty, about deception and even corruption in government. The Government admits to no principles at all and admits to no precedents in the way that it governs. The precedents change day by day and week by week, depending on which Minister is in trouble and on which party that Minister belongs to. At any time, but particularly in times of economic and social crisis, the reality and the perception of an efficient, competent and honest government is important to maintain stability and progress in this country. We have increasing instability. We have a lack of confidence because at all levels of government we are faced with inconsistency and a lack of direction. We are faced with corruption and the smell of corruption. Above all we have the mentality at the highest level of government which seeks scapegoats for its failings, whether they be unions, businesses, in particular public servants and sometimes the Opposition, and now a royal commissioner, who is a distinguished judge and an ex-head of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Everyone is blamed; everyone is considered responsible for the ills of this country except the Government itself . In particular, Ministers not only fail to take responsibility for their own actions-a constitutional responsibility, as pointed out by Senator Button-but also fail to take responsibility for the actions of their departments, for which they are responsible, and blame especially those public servants for whom they are responsible for the difficulties they face.

I suggest that it is this lack of responsibility combined with the scandals, petty and otherwise, which have beset this Government, and the failure of the Prime Minister to demand responsible behaviour from his Ministers and to take a consistent line when dealing with irresponsible behaviour, which has led to the perception and reality of a lack of morality in high public office in this country. If the Government of the day acts like a pack of power hungry, irresponsible mafiosi it is no wonder that its friends in other places indulge in the tax evasion, tax avoidance and fraudulent behaviour that have been demonstrated in recent months and years. It is no wonder that members of the Public Service-or some sections of it-directionless and seeing the behaviour of those who are put in charge of them, in some cases forget their responsibilities to the people. The vast majority of officers of the Public Service are honest and conscientious. It must be hard for some of them to be so in this country.

On 1 April 1980 Mr N. A. Brown-now the Honourable N. A. Brown, a Minister of the Government-presented to the House of Representatives a report of a delegation which he had led to Zimbabwe, which was then known as Rhodesia. He said:
We have the principle of ministerial responsibility under the system of government that was elected in free and fair elections in Rhodesia. It is a pity that it is not practised more often here.

He compared unfavourably the principle of ministerial responsibility as it applied in this country with that applied in Zimbabwe at the time. Of course, he is now a Minister and must be mute on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is Acting Attorney- General.

—Indeed. He is acting as the first law officer of this country. Those were his views only two short years ago. One wonders whether privately they are his views now. We saw the spectacle yesterday of the Prime Minister castigating the royal commissioner who, as I said, was a distinguished judge, and a former colleague of his, Bert Kelly, whose integrity, consistency and honesty have never been questioned inside or outside of this Parliament. He castigated departmental officers also, in a tedious speech which was over an hour long and tried to justify his failure to deal with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) in the way he had dealt with the previous Ministers such as Senator Withers, Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar. The Prime Minister in the course of his speech referred to what he called 'significant breakdowns and administrative failures in areas of public administration'. It seems that when it suits him we have a supporter in the Prime Minister. He referred to the Narcotics Bureau, the Australian Federal Police and the Crown Solicitor's Office. But there have been many more breakdowns and administrative failures than theirs. They have affected not only the revenue of this country but also the civil liberties, rights and freedoms of many Australians. In these and other cases the failure to administer responsibility and to accept the responsibility attached to high public office has led to some of the more disgraceful episodes in the recent history of our public life.

SPEECH.PARA: We should look at some of those episodes. Firstly, let us look at what should have been the petty case of the colour television set which so upset Senator Carrick. A Minister of the Crown failed to fill out his Customs declaration because he was tired. He got his secretary to do so and quite illegally sign the form for him. He then evaded duty payable for the television. If he did not, why was he sacked?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think you are wrong. Are you sure it was illegal to do so?
—It is not illegal.
—If it is not illegal, why was he sacked? Another Minister, when this incident was brought to his notice, either voluntarily or under instructions tried to cover up the incident.
—Under instructions.

—It may well have been done under instructions. I point out that a public servant who at the time persisted in doing his duty was subjected to the grossest pressure to rethink the truth, to desist in his efforts, but he persisted. Eventually the two Ministers, the one carrying the television set and the other carrying the can, were retired to the back bench, where presumably they are now plotting their resurrection.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened to the honest and persistent public servant? He was invalided out of the Public Service-a burnt-out case, a victim of the scandal as much as anybody else, and who in the Government cares? Who, including Senator Martin, gives a damn? How many others over the years have tried to do their duty in the way in which this man did and failed? How many will sit on their reports and not persist in their duty because it is just not worth the candle? How many more Customs officers, tax assessors, meat inspectors, or others, will look at the example shown to them by their Ministers and come to the conclusion that the best way to survive is to turn a blind eye; to be in it, if that is the way things are to be? We should spare a thought for the vast majority of honest, efficient public servants who, because of failure of leadership by example from the top-and from lower ranks also-and given the sorts of examples that have been shown them, must wonder why they persist in the duties that they are doing.

I give one example which occurred in 1978. That was the year of the social security fraud case, when 178 Greek Australian citizens were subject to harassment through dawn raids. It was the year in which the Department of Health told the then Minister for Health that overservicing and fraud were costing $ 100m. No action was taken; the Minister took no notice. In 1978, it will be remembered, a tax evasion case was tangled in the offices of the Deputy Crown Solicitor, the Crown Solicitor and the Commissioner of Taxation. No action was taken and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said in a statement to this Parliament that he took no action because the public was not sufficiently concerned about the matter. In 1978 Senator Primmer made a statement to the Senate detailing allegations of malpractice in the meat industry. No action was taken; the Minister displayed no interest in it. However, the law enforcement agencies at the time, which were unwilling to take on the big targets-the doctors and the culpable company directors-and had no reason to believe that the relevant Ministers were serious about their taking any action, were eager to take on the easiest targets of all, the social security pensioners. So willing was the Government to believe its own propaganda about social security frauds that it was open to believing that a preposterous conspiracy was raging in the Greek community.

We all know what has happened. Ten million dollars and four years later the case has collapsed. The magistrate has criticised the Government and the Crown Solicitor's Office for believing a man whom he describes as a liar and for taking notice of a detective constable at the time whom he describes as having no credibility and whose case should be considered with a view to a charge of perjury and conspiracy against the Crown being laid. Nothing has happened in the three months since. No action has been taken by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to see what has happened to the nine people who, as a result of the evidence of this man, were charged in Greece for offences in Australia. We have a feeling at the highest level, that of the Attorney-General, that this was all a sad mistake and should not have happened but it is not his responsibility to do anything about it.

It is that sort of lack of responsibility, lack of consistency and failure on the part of the Prime Minister to take action in cases such as these involving senior Ministers of his Government-as well as the actions referred to by Senator Button-that will bring us back again and again to this chamber to talk about the declining standards of administration and morality of the present Government. As Senator Button says, we will persist in doing so until this Government is removed by the people who have that power-the electors of this country.
