In my opinion, this is an example of irresponsibility by honourable senators on the other side of this chamber. I suggest that this debate was instigated by a party that for three years presided over an administration that I regard as the worst this country has seen. I remember some recent words written by Mr Clyde Cameron.
—You do not remember them; you just read them.

—The honourable senator should not worry about that. I regard the Honourable Clyde Cameron as a quite credible person who is astute in his criticism of the former Whitlam Government. As we are talking about efficiency of administration, I think a chapter entitled 'The Public Service Rip-Off' in his book Unions in Crisis, is worth quoting in part:

SPEECH.PARA: But this chapter does more than that; it shows that the outbreak of wage dissatisfaction in 1974 was the direct result of a Government's dunderheaded doting on trade union officialdom and its failure to distinguish between the greed, and need, of its own employees. Some of us understood plasterers, lawyers and medicos; but only three of the 27 Labor Ministers understood Public Service guile and these appeared too embarrassed to share their secret.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Mr Clyde Cameron, a former Minister of the Whitlam Government, said that.
—About Whitlam Ministers?
—He was talking about Whitlam Ministers. He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Our creed amounted to this. 'We mustn't oppose anything, no matter how extreme, that is put to us by a union official or we will be branded as 'anti-union' and then our preselectors will know we are also anti-Labor.' Those certainly appeared to be the principal guidelines governing the thought processes of the majority of Cabinet Ministers when I asked them to reject the stage-managed wage increase which the Public Service Board employees offered to their own union in 1973.

It was plain as a pikestaff that we were being 'mugged' for a wage rip-off. But , so what? They were unionists weren't they? And so, the fuse was lit to the explosion that occurred a few months later. And yet no-one seemed to understand the connection between salary rises in the Public Service, and the wage demands that were to flare up in the private sector from early 1974 onwards.
He went on to talk about white collar crime:

. . . no-one suspected it was happening because the thieves wore waistcoats, travelled in Z cars, affected the dignity of dukes and had agents to leak Government secrets to the media in return for 'protection'.

That is the sort of efficiency that prevailed in the Australian Labor Party Administration in those days. We are still suffering for it. This Government has been trying to get out of the mess created by the maladministration and poor government administration of those days.

Senator Button, in his inimitable way, chose to be rather humorous and cynical about the Honourable Sir James Killen and his department of five employees. I imagine that five employees would be relatively easy to manage and it would be relatively easy to detect whether there was maladministration in those quarters. However, we should examine the numbers in other departments. According to the Public Service Board report, the numbers in the departments of the various Ministers who have been mentioned are quite considerable. For example, the Attorney-General's Department has 2,600 employees. It is important, too, to remember that the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union went back to 1972, during the years of the Whitlam Administration. That department was then under the so- called supervision of the Attorney-General, then Senator Murphy. The Department of Social Security, administered by Senator Chaney, has 13,275 employees. The Treasury has even more. There are about 18,000 people in the Treasury under the supervision of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). How can one possibly look over the shoulders of 18,000 people to ensure that they are doing their jobs correctly? Ministers have to rely quite definitely on the advice they are given from time to time by their senior officers and the section leaders within their departments.

It is appropriate to refer to just one or two comments made in respect of ministerial responsibility. I refer to the The Canberra Model, an essay on Australian Government by David Butler, a Fellow of the Nuffield College, Oxford, and Visiting Fellow at the Australian National University in 1967 and 1972. Under the heading 'Ministerial Responsibility', he has this to say:
Consider first individual ministerial responsibility. Its central doctrine is that for every public act of a public servant for a ministerial department, a minister has to answer to parliament.
He goes on to say:

Individual ministerial responsibility is easy to ridicule. How can a minister take responsibility for the innumerable acts of his civil servants, many of them involving technicalities of which he could not conceivably be master?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about when he gets to know about it?
—I go on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: But to answer does not mean to take the blame in a personal way; still less does it mean to resign. To answer only requires a minister to say 'I have ministerial responsibility for this. I am sorry that a mistake has been made. I have taken steps to see that it does not happen again.'

I suggest to Senator Button, with respect to the Costigan Royal Commission and his criticiisms of the Government following that, that when the Labor Party was in government it identified one or two tax evasion schemes but did nothing about it. The Labor Government vaguely made the statement 'Oh yes, we'll do this', but 12 months later nothing had happened. Then the Fraser Government came to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —And did nothing.

—We set up the Costigan Commission. We broadened the terms of reference to allow matters such as taxation subjects to be dealt with. I do not think that that can be regarded by anybody as a failure properly to administer. We showed a lead to the former Labor Government. We showed that we were prepared to seal up the loopholes with respect to tax evasion schemes and we were prepared to do something about the problem. All of us in this chamber are very concerned about tax rip-offs by entrepreneurs who promote these tax evasion schemes and suck innocent people into them. We are desperately anxious to deal with them. We have shown the Government's intention to do just that. But the Labor Party, of course, would not have the mentality or foresight to set up a commission such as the Costigan Commission, so that a Government has before it information requiring action, as it has now.

SPEECH.PARA: Action is being carried out. Certain officers have been charged under the Public Service Act. They are extremely culpable and will be dealt with according to the processes of the law. The Government has established the office of special prosecutor, whose work will be to examine the evidence that has been presented against people who have been named in the Costigan report in order to gather sufficient evidence to enable the Government to take action against those offenders who are involved with illegal taxation avoidance or evasion schemes. Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned a Crimes commission. We recognise that major crime in Australia is clearly a growing problem. We are having consultations with the States. Some States have not agreed entirely with the proposition, but I understand that consultation is continuing. I am quite sure that the State governments will recognise the tremendous significance of co-operating with the Commonwealth to establish a crimes commission to deal with major crime in Australia.

When the people of Australia listen to the facts associated with this matter, they will realise that the present Government is certainly on the track to dealing with the problems revealed by the Costigan report. It is quite irresponsible of the Opposition to bring this matter before the Senate today. The Opposition has a gall in doing so, because it has done nothing to deal with the tremendous problem of tax evasion. The Fraser Government has come to grips with it and is doing something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has raised as a matter of public importance today the rapidly declining standards of government administration. We have had a wild but insubstantial response from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) and a rather pathetic defence from Senator Jessop. It is worth pointing out that the Government does not even have a full slate of speakers for the debate. Senator Jessop said that the Labor Government did nothing about tax evasion. Of course, tax evasion had barely begun at that stage, but even though it had barely begun, the Labor Government had authorised prosecutions in 1975. Senator Jessop spoke rather rapidly in saying that the Fraser Government came to office and set up the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, ignoring the fact that there were about seven years in between those two events.

SPEECH.PARA: The standards of the present Government have always left much to be desired. Those standards have gradually got worse and worse. In recent times the rate of that decline has accelerated, which has just been paralleled by the rate of the decline in the Government's fortunes. What is more, the Government knows it. It is a guilty Government. One can tell that from how its members look. The Ministers look sick, and those behind them do as well. They know that they are guilty. I suggest they are physically and mentally exhausted from running around in circles trying to plug up all their problems. I heard someone say recently: ' Gee, the Ministers of this Government look crook'-to which someone answered, ' Yes, they are not looking too well, either'. They have not done their duty.

The conservatives were dismissed in 1972 for being tired and incompetent. During the period of the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975, they ranted and raved at having lost what they thought was their God-given right to govern. As we all know, they took desperate and immoral actions to counter that. They are still ranting and raving about the actions of the Whitlam Government. We had the amazing claim by Senator Sir John Carrick that there had been 35 Ministers go in the Labor Government. Everyone knows that that is just a fabrication. I presume that he was including those at the end of the term who lost their positions as a result of the actions of this Senate in denying supply. One thing that can be said is that there was never any taint of corruption about our Ministers. Certainly a couple got into strife, but only because they tried to administer the country actively; it was not because of neglect and that sort of thing.

The present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) came to power with many high sounding words. He promised integrity and honesty of government, so that, he said, he could have the confidence and trust of the people. Admittedly, he managed to convince the electorate that his Government was not as bad as we said it was, for a couple of elections. But now at least, as the standards have declined even further and the revelations of past slipped standards have increased, it is clearly perceived by everyone, including the present Government 's supporters, that it is in disgrace and on the slide. I do not think that anyone has any argument about that. It is only a matter of time before the Government goes.

That is all very good for us, as an opposition. We benefit politically and, ultimately, electorally. But it is not good for the nation that we have such a bumbling and incompetent government lurching from crisis to crisis. There are new examples daily of unacceptably poor administration. As a result of this, the whole nation loses its self-respect. Australians ought to be able to be proud of the way in which their country is administered, even if they disagree with the ideology of the government in power. Such pride is just not possible at present in respect of this Government. The Prime Minister cannot afford any more sackings or resignations, because he is already at the bottom of the barrel. Let us look at those he has lost by one means or another.

Mr Garland has been mentioned. A point that ought to be made in response to Senator Sir John Carrick is that he did not give the true situation in his response about Mr Garland, because Mr Garland was not acquitted. The magistrate ruled that a prima facie case had been established but did not proceed to let it go to the jury. So, there was Mr Garland. There was Mr McLeay; Withers, Peacock, MacKellar, Moore, Groom and a number of others. Apart from that, others have gone and come back, such as Sir Phillip Lynch and Mr Sinclair, who are still under a cloud. Yet more have been dropped down the scale. Look at Mr Viner. Look at Sir James Killen, the Minister for nothing-although, of course, as was said earlier, how well he does it. Some of the remaining Ministers just keep their heads down. They think that if they do nothing they will not get into trouble. How wrong some of them will be proved to be. It is not good administration either. Because they believe they have a God-given right to govern, they think they need to govern only benignly.

The rest of the Ministry ranges from the bumbling inadequacy of, say, a Newman- it is amazing that he has survived so long-through to the mere public relations hype of a Hodgman, who provides much waving of arms but how many Australian Capital Territory residents are happy with him, to the never giving of an answer to a question without notice of a Guilfoyle, who also allowed the social security conspiracy witch-hunt, and to the continuing receipt of a 4 per cent interest loan of an Anthony, a person at Deputy Prime Minister level. Then there is the Prime Minister, the Fraser of double standards, who will not accept resignations that he ought to accept and who does not ask for others for which he ought to ask. We have Ministers who were, at the very least, culpably negligent in respect of medical fraud and in their failure to deal properly with tax evasion and avoidance. Most recently Minister Nixon has provided us with one thing after another in respect of the administration of the Department of Primary Industry. I refer to the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal, the meat substitution scandal and it now appears possibly something relating to fisheries.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations ought to be working itself out of business, but it is getting more and more work. It is being overloaded with work because of Ministers like Mr Nixon. The Government, of course, answers that many of these matters involve public servants as well as Ministers. That is so but Ministers are ultimately responsible unless they did not know and could not have been expected to know the situation. In all of the cases that we are talking about Ministers either did know or could have been expected to know or to find out. What has happened is a passing of the blame to public servants generally, trying to make them the scapegoat. As the Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, Paul Munro, said yesterday or earlier today:
The Federal Government's intended major examination of the Public Service is an attempt to divert public attention from the hapless performances of ministers . . .
He went on to say that he:
. . . did not condone personal dishonesty among public servants and recognised that this may exist.
However, we protest strongly at any attempt at scape-goating the Public Service .
. . . if a Minister was soft on a matter, be it tax avoidance or protecting the meat export trade, it was unrealistic to expect the Public Service to be hard.

Any review or examination of the Public Service for fault should be accompanied by an even harder examination of Ministers and Cabinet, which had primary responsibility throughout including that of resource allocation.

As that statement points out there is no need to be a blind defender of the Public Service. Whilst the majority of public servants are conscientious and as efficient as they are allowed to be, of course there are some who damage the good name of the Public Service. It is very frustrating and annoying when this happens. But what can this Government expect from the Public Service? A low standard government can only tend to be reflected by lower standards in the Public Service. This Government preaches survival of the fittest; it encourages everyone to get what he can out of the system. Is it any wonder that we end up with the meat scandal, with tax evasion and with medifraud? No encouragement is given to people to pay tax as an honourable activity in accordance with their ability to pay. Of course the public reacts accordingly and the Public Service reacts accordingly.

On top of that the Government continually disparages and denigrates the Public Service. It imposes unreasonable staff ceilings and at the same time expects more activity out of public servants. This Government has tried to knock the fair and caring attitude out of everyone. There is no encouragement of a fair and reasonable attitude in the community. This Government has continually sold out those who have been involved in public administration. It has given away traditional public responsibilities to the private sector. It has reduced the effectiveness of Telecom Australia and Australia Post and dismissed staff and taken away their role. Is it any wonder that the Governmen sometimes cannot obtain full co-operation from some public servants?

As I have suggested the Opposition is not in favour of excess fat in the Public Service and nor does it condone poor administration. We want a tight administration and we will have it after we come to government next year or later this year. I would like to inject a positive note into the debate by reminding honourable senators about the Labor Opposition's task force on Government administration which was involved in preparing recommendations for the Caucus before the 1980 election. It was re-elected during this Parliament and has recently distributed its report to Caucus members. It provides a thorough look at how a Labor Government will efficiently, thoroughly, honestly and credibly provide a high standard of administration. The Labor Party is taking the responsibility of government seriously.

One ought to mention also, of course, that the present Liberal Government's administration has caused bad management of the economy and a high level of unemployment and it has taken no action to overcome them. The current mess of ministerial impropriety and lack of attention to the real work of government means that the Government is distracted from its deeper policy lapses. It also means, unfortunately, that the public is distracted from those deeper and more important policy lapses. How can Government members run the country when they are running around with their heads off as they are present? It is an appalling government. It has led to an appallingly low morale in the Public Service.

From the head of a department to the lowest clerical assistant there ought to be pride in the outfit he or she is working for, but that cannot be expected under this Government. It is unfit for government; it is just not up to the job. It is a hick government which has allowed the Public Service to risk gaining the same sort of reputation which has been attributed in the past to local government. It will take a long time and some careful nurturing to regain the proper reputation. This Government will never be able to do that. It must go so that a Labor Government, with higher standards, can be installed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with amazement to the debate this afternoon on the matter of public importance raised by the Australian Labor Party. In recent weeks the standard of debate in the Senate, as a result of the conduct of the Opposition on debating issues that it has raised, has lowered the standard of the Senate considerably. But I do not think anything is as sad a reflection on the Opposition as its conduct this afternoon. As I sat here and listened to the words of Senator Button, Senator Grimes and Senator Coates I have had a mental vision of what it must have been like when the British colonisers landed in a new country and were greeted by the ignorant savages. Those colonisers threw around coloured beads with gay abandon believing that the ignorant savages would believe them to be valuable when, in fact, they were worthless. What the ALP is doing in the Senate in debate, particularly this afternoon, is tossing around words, allegations and imputations of impropriety as though they were coloured beads and as though all those who are listening and who might subsequently read the debate will react to them as ignorant savages.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the most extraordinary statements made which cut against all the fact on issues that have previously been debated in this chamber; matters on which papers have been tabled and made available to all honourable senators, including Opposition senators and from which statements and conclusions have been made by Senator Grimes in particular which bear no relationship whatsoever to documents publicly available and statements which are actually on the record.

I shall have the opportunity to pick up a couple of those issues but nobody would be able to pick up all the allegations that have been made with such rapid fire style here this afternoon. Of course there is an amount of repetition in the allegations. We are told that the matter of public importance that the Opposition believes that the other business of the Senate should be set aside for to debate, is a matter of standards of government administration. We have had what has now become a repetitive litany of statements about individuals, present Ministers and former Ministers of successive Fraser Governments. It has reached the stage where, in preparing for a debate on a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition, regardless of how it chooses to phrase it, all one has to do is to read a catalogue of previous speeches made by Labor Party leaders in this chamber and by Mr Hayden, Mr Bowen and others in the other chamber to know exactly what is going to be said.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—That is right, Senator Button. That is all one has to do. It is a waste of time to listen. The sad thing is that the same misstatements and the same misrepresentations are made over and over again. Very clearly, the Labor Party believes, disgracefully believes, that if one repeats an allegation often enough, whether it is true or not, people will believe it; that it will take on the patina of truth; or perhaps it hopes that the Government will become weary of rejecting the same tedious untrue allegations.
—Which ones were untrue?

—I will come to that. I will deal with one in particular from Senator Grimes. In his speech he made a reference to me on a subject on which I have spoken in the Senate and on which my view is on the record. If he had read the Senate debate on that subject on a previous occasion this year he would have known what was said by me, as the Government speaker, on that specific subject. But he did not, as I dare say he has not read the papers that were tabled either . What they indicate is something very different from what Senator Grimes, via the air waves, has chosen to have people believe this afternoon. The Opposition obviously also believes that if there is sufficient mud slinging some of it will stick, as indeed I dare say some of it does. But some mud also sticks to the hands of those who sling it. By making such loose and wild accusations, the Labor Party is muddied.

SPEECH.PARA: The cavalier attitude to facts was very clearly illustrated during the speech by Senator Grimes, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place, in statements he made in reference to Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore. He said that Mr MacKellar had failed to fill in a form, had allowed his secretary to sign it and there by broke the law. That is just not true. Mr MacKellar did not break the law by allowing someone else to fill in a form and sign it for him. If Senator Grimes will take the time to read that debate and to read papers associated with it he will find what the alleged offence was. It did not have to do with what he put in his shorthand form this afternoon. Even worse, he then went on to say that Mr John Moore either voluntarily or under pressure covered up for Mr MacKellar. With a little encouragement from interjections from his side, he then put heavy emphasis on the statement 'under pressure'.

The record shows that Mr Moore sought, through the Secretary of his Department, an investigation by the Department of the allegations. The Secretary of his Department subsequently told him that he had investigated the matters and that there was no duty payable on the set that Mr MacKellar brought into Australia. The record shows that in the form of a minute written by the Secretary of the Department. Mr Moore had pursued the issue, had sought an investigation, had taken it seriously and had accepted that, when the Secretary of his Department told him that an investigation had been carried out and that no duty was payable , the Secretary of his Department was telling him the truth. There is no other basis under which a Minister can proceed. To suggest that Mr Moore was responding to any sort of pressure from higher up or from beside him is just disgraceful. There has never been anything to suggest anything of that kind and facts that have been available for months have shown the opposite.

One can only speculate on the difficulties that the Opposition Whip, Senator Robertson, had in drawing up the speakers' list for today's debate. The speakers ' list that I have in front of me shows three Labor senators-Senators Button, Grimes and Coates. In fact we have had several other Labor senators attempting to enter the debate. We had Senators Gietzelt, Walsh and Bolkus earlier and now Senator Robert Ray comes in for his shift to try to take over some of the debate . I say to Senator Ray: 'Speak more sweetly next time to Senator Robertson. In fact, practise speaking sweetly and you might be able to insinuate yourself on to a speakers' list and get a turn'. That is all I have to say to Senator Ray because he does not have anything worth responding to. There are certain principles relating to administration and to responsibility and the Westminster style of government-a phrase much quoted and much printed these days-and they have been dealt with in many publications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about them, Senator.

—I shall, Senator. Senator Button needs to know about them. I intend to tell him about them. There have been suggestions that the conduct of this Government and the way Ministers have carried out their responsibilities somehow is deserving of condemnation. I will quote from a document of the Australian Senate. It is a report on the Freedom of Information Bill from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I remind the Senate-I place this fact on record-that there are three Government and three Opposition senators on this Committee. The three Opposition senators are all Labor senators. They are Senators Evans, Tate and Keeffe. The Committee brought in a unanimous report so one takes it that this is the view of at least that group of Labor senators, and that no others have taken exception to that report, on the subject of the Westminster system and specifically on the subject of ministerial responsibility-what is owed to Parliament by Ministers and implicitly by the Government. On page 34 of that report this interesting statement appears:

SPEECH.PARA: In this chapter we analyse exactly what the 'Westminster system' is, both in theory and practice.
The next paragraph starts:
There is no precise definition of the Westminster system in the real sense,

One would think that a small contradiction but it is interesting as an introduction to just some of the difficulties one can get into on this subject. However, the Committee was not deterred. That sentence continued:

and it is unlikely that there ever could be because so much of what is understood as essential to the system is informal, depending upon traditions, conventions and understandings that do not admit of precise formulation.
Nevertheless, the Committee went on to attempt a formulation. The report states:
Although we do not offer any definition of the Westminster system, we can quite easily state what have traditionally been held to be the key elements of it, . . .
Under the characteristic features, the Committee stated:

. . . there is a doctrine of individual ministerial responsibility which holds that each minister is personally responsible for all of the decisions made and carried out by the department which he heads;

TALK.START.PARA: —That's Fraser's first version.
—That is the version of a Senate committee.
—No, that's Fraser's first version.
—Well the Senate Committee comes to a final decision. I know Senator Button has not read the report.
—I have read the report.

—Senator Button says he has read the report. But he has forgotten it because it has not been reflected in what he has been saying in the Senate in the last couple of weeks. The Committee report also states:

SPEECH.PARA: No part of the Westminster system has been so thoroughly criticised, nor has any part so thoroughly changed, as the doctrine of individual ministerial responsibility. . . . It must be remembered that this doctrine developed in the days when departments of State were small and it was a reasonable assumption that ministers of state were familiar with everything that went on in their departments.

Political practices have changed, and the twin forces of the increasing complexity and scope of departments of State (meaning that no one believes that ministers can be 'on top' of everything) and the development of party solidarity . . . (meaning that political parties rally to protect their own members from political attacks)-
We remember that was the view of the Labor Party too. That sentence continues:
have fundamentally eroded this doctrine.

The very size and complexity of modern departments inevitably means tha the chances of these mistakes, even on a large scale, will multiply. For instance, in August 1977 the Auditor-General pointed out that the Department of Social Security had overpaid benefits to the extent of $40m but the Minister did not feel obliged to resign, and neither did anyone seriously call for her resignation.
One assumes that that includes the Labor Party and the Opposition. They did not seriously call for her resignation. So that has been an accepted practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we did on other occasions.
—I make one comment on that since Senator Grimes seeks to enter the debate. As I recall, Senator Grimes referred to this matter in his speech.
—He was wrong.

—He was wrong. He used the figure $100m. I suppose it is just a matter of degree whether it is $40m or $100m. The facts of the Auditor-General's report relevant to the occasion to which Senator Grimes referred are freely available.
—It was the Health Department.

—Senator Grimes was referring to a specific case and how the Government reacted to it. That is the specific case and there was a government reaction to it. I am glad that Senator Grimes has re-entered the chamber because I should like to refer him yet again to a misstatement he has made in relation to me and to make an explanation about it. In referring to a Customs officer, Senator Grimes said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . who in the Government cares? Who, including Senator Martin, gives a damn?

I suggest to Senator Grimes that he read my speech in the debate on the incident in question and he will find that I was sympathetic to the position that that man was put into. There has been no suggestion from the Government of any contrary situation on that matter. Senator Grimes's allegations were cavalier in their attitude to the facts and the great danger is that the Australian Labor Party is showing signs of believing its own propaganda. Senator Grimes, in conclusion, said that the Opposition will persist in raising this matter in the Senate. I have no doubt at all that the Opposition will persist in raising this matter in the Senate. That is its right. I just say that I hope it will not continue to persist in misrepresentation of individuals, of events in which they have been involved, of government actions and of the facts. I hope that in persisting to raise the issue it will do so telling the truth and dealing fairly with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation. I take my cue from the other side. The previous speaker, Senator Martin, claimed that I had said that $ 100m was overspent by the Department of Social Security and that this was a matter that I referred to in my speech. I think if she reads Hansard she will find that I referred to $100m lost to the revenue through Medibank frauds and that it was nothing to do with the Department of Social Security. Her hearing is as good as her accuracy with facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last hour and a half the Senate has witnessed the rather sad spectacle of the two old political parties throwing mud at each other. If honourable senators do not realise it, I can assure them that the public realises very clearly that it is a matter of the kettle calling the pot black. The unfortunate fact is that both the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party have been subjected, over the last few months, to accusations of support from elements in the community which they wish were not supporting them. I refer to corrupt big business and to corrupt trade unions. If ever there was a need for a new political party, the evidence of the last few weeks has surely demonstrated that better than it has ever been demonstrated before. We need a political party that is not supported by forces in the community which have been shown so obviously to be corruptible and to have influenced the political system of this country directly through their associations with the Labor Party and the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to become involved in the mud slinging exercise. This debate relates to 'the rapidly declining standards of government administration'. When I read the topic of this matter of public importance, I was delighted, because I felt that the Senate had at last put its finger on the nerve centre of what is wrong with this country, which is, without a doubt, poor administration. I suggest that to administer this country successfully we first of all have to embrace certain basic principles of administration. These principles of administration apply in business and they certainly should apply in the business of running the country. In my very brief sojourn in this chamber I have seen these principles eroded. I have seen these basic principles torn asunder as though the country could be administered without reference to them. I intend to spend the few minutes available to me in reminding honourable senators of these principles that must be embraced if we are to get back to running this country as it should be run and getting it out of the problems which are surrounding it on every side.

The first principle undoubtedly, whether it applies to the running of the country or the running of business, is accountability. Where does the buck stop? That accountability must start at the top. Ministers have to accept responsibility. To suggest that a Minister, the political head of a large body of people, can use as an excuse the fact that he was not informed or that he did not know what was going on is simply to put that Minister and all Ministers, if that is to be the accepted principle, in the position of mere puppets. The Minister, as head of the department, has to accept the responsibility for what goes on in the department, as does the department itself. If there is no accountability at the top, I suggest that down the line also there is a great lack of accountability.

We see the operation these days of interdepartmental committees. What effect do those committees have? Their operation means that departments can shelve responsibility. They collectively assess matters of policy but nobody can say clearly who was responsible for what. In the old days of Curtin, Chifley and Menzies, it was very clearly laid down where the responsibility lay within the government administration. The Minister was clearly responsible, as was the head of the department. The first area of concern, to me at least, is simply the whole principle, from the top down, of accountability.

The second principle, I suggest, is developing an organisational structure which allows people an area of responsibility in which they can use their human qualities, their technical expertise and their initiative. In the administration of government clearly this means that we have to have some system of measuring output. People have to understand and be shown clearly what is expected of them. This is not happening at the moment. In a company structure, unless one is prepared to state clearly to people where their responsibilities start and finish and to measure their performance, one will not get efficiency. As far as I can see, this principle applies equally to the Public Service. Why cannot small groups of people be told clearly what is expected of them and why cannot their performance be monitored on a regular basis? There is nothing more soul destroying than to be part of a large organisation where nobody is measuring one 's performance and nobody is aware of what one is doing and whether one is doing it well or badly.

My third criticism of government administration relates to the location of Canberra and its isolation from the business community of this country. Canberra is a delightful place to live but it happens to be just too far away from Sydney , Melbourne, and the other State capitals. About 12 months ago the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures conducted a survey of the backgrounds of parliamentarians. The survey revealed that of all parliamentarians-members and senators from both sides of the Houses-only four had a background in business. I think one of those four was a second hand car salesman and another was involved in the administration of some business associated with the trade union movement. A large number of our politicians are doctors, lawyers and farmers. Very few have had practical experience in administration. I suggest that this, in association with the isolation of Canberra, means that we have a very serious problem.

How do we solve it? It is interesting to note what Roosevelt said when he came to power during the 1930 Depression. He said, in effect: 'I have received all kinds of advice from the business sector. I am now President of the United States and I will call into my administration the people who gave the advice. They can now take the responsibility for trying to fix the country'. It is interesting that a President reorganised the administration by bringing in people who had practical administrative experience. I believe that if we are to do justice to our country we need people of proven administrative backgrounds. Canberra must have the best brains in the country. This can happen only if the Government adopts a new approach to administration that will allow people of experience to work in areas of responsibility involved in the running of the country.

At the present time, we are going through a period in which there is a scandal every second day. Accusations are flying around this chamber and the other place . As a result, the real problems of our economy are receiving very slight attention. The level of unemployment is mounting at a dangerously rapid pace. We have a dangerous balance of payments problem. But who is doing anything about that? We have just seen the introduction of a Budget in respect of which, in spite of its hand-outs, the economic approach is essentially that which we have been through over the last three years. The Budget provides for another domestic surplus and another tight economic approach to the management of the country.

Sooner or later we have to do something about the crisis that is around us. We must have firm government direction. I get the impression that we are riding in an aeroplane which is in a tail spin with nobody at the controls. In 1952 Australia faced a not dissimilar problem to the one we are facing today. At that time we had mounting inflation and a critical balance of payments problem. The Government of the day under Robert Menzies said that the time had come for action. He laid down a whole series of new initiatives. We must have some new initiatives for the economic management of the country if we are to solve the problems that are surrounding us. We are facing probably the worst drought in the nation's history. We are facing a period in which commodity prices are escalating. Unless we change the economic direction, inevitably we will be in a situation as bad as that of the 1930s. So the challenge is there. We have to revamp our administration. We have to bring into administration the best brains in the country, people who have a proven administrative experience.

Above all, we have to be prepared to adopt and embrace the very first principle of good management and good administration which is accountability. That accountability starts with Ministers. It then has to be organised to apply right down the line. I do not wish to imply any criticism of the Public Service as such in anything that I have said. I believe from what I have seen that the Public Service is a body of dedicated people who perform brilliantly within the parameters that they are given. But they are not organised in a way that allows them to come to grips with the problems that are facing them on all sides. The problem starts at the top; it starts with the Government; and it starts with the way the Government has organised and is organising the Public Service. We have to get right away from interdepartmental committees. We must be prepared to say to a head of a department: 'There is your responsibility. It is clearly laid out . That is what we expect of you'. The head of the department in turn has to pass that responsibility all the way down the line. I think the Senate has put its finger on this critical area. We must do something to improve the situation. We must in fact have a complete change of direction in the way that we have been administering this country.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-The documents I have tabled can broadly be broken into three groups. First, there is a fairly detailed chronology of the Government's handling of straw companies and the development of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in the period 1978-1980 together with a detailed listing of other tax issues taken to Cabinet, legislation introduced and Press releases on tax initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Second, there is a batch of documents consisting of memoranda from the Commissioner, diary notes and correspondence between departments and Ministers, et cetera, that relate to the Government's handling of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act over the same period. Documents in this group that the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) personally did not see at the time have been identified by an asterisk.

The third batch consists of three legal opinions. The Solicitor-General has considered that counsel's opinions and other legal advice referred to in items 2 , 7, 12, 13, 14, 16, 19, 20, 21 and 22 of the Senate resolution should not be tabled on the ground that public disclosure of the contents would be harmful to the administration of justice. He personally examined each of the documents in question. He has stated that, in his view, harm would be caused both to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly, or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant. In many instances both sides would be injured. That injury would not, in his view, be avoided by excising names. The Solicitor-General has reached a similar conclusion in relation to the police investigation report referred to in item 15.

The Government has decided that it should accept the advice of the Solicitor- General on this matter. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) believes that there is no other proper course that the Government could follow, even though the opinions, if they were able to be tabled, would show that counsels' opinions were not all 'one way' on the availability of adequate and effective legal remedies in the cases that they related to. Thus, the opinion of counsel referred to in item 2 of the Evans motion advised that there was insufficient evidence to warrant criminal proceedings on a charge under section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act . The Lockhart opinion referred to in item 7 of the motion, while it advised of reasonable prospects of success, recognised the difficulties inherent in establishing a charge of conspiracy to defraud or similar charges. The Attorney- General (Senator Durack) pointed out to the Senate on 7 September 1982 that this opinion did not relate to a 'bottom-of-the-harbour' scheme. He also referred to the question of further action being taken on this case and made the obvious point, now confirmed by the Solicitor-General, that the opinion should not be tabled.

The documents show a number of things. These include: First, apart from the reference in the minute of 24 May 1978 which the Treasurer has already referred to in the House, no reference, directly or indirectly, was made in any document coming to the Treasurer from the Commissioner of Taxation or anyone else regarding the circumstances surrounding what ultimately has become known as the Perth case reported upon by Mr Costigan. As the Treasurer has already said, he does not believe it can fairly be said that the reference in the minute of 24 May should of itself have placed him on further inquiry regarding the circumstances of that case.

Secondly, as the Treasurer said in his reply to the McCabe-Lafranchi report, the Australian Taxation Office regularly passed on information to the Treasurer regarding straw company activity and strongly pressed for introduction of proposals which, with important changes, became embodied in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980.

Thirdly, from very early in the piece, both the concept and scope of the proposals put to the Treasurer by the Australian Taxation Office and which were ultimately incorporated in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act because of their unprecedented character as far as the tax law was concerned, required careful consideration by the Treasurer and the Government. There was concern not only about what represented a new approach in this area of the tax law, but also any reversal of the onus of proof in criminal matters. That concern was shared by the relevant Government members' committee and most strongly by the Taxation Advisory Committee. Concern about the nature of and opposition to the legislation continued until and beyond the time of its passage in December 1980.

Fourthly, the period covered by the documents saw an unprecedented volume of political, administrative and legislative action against tax avoidance of which the area covered by the straw company issue was but one part.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: My initial reaction to this document is that I suppose it is comparable to the character of the scandal with which we are dealing, which I have described as the greatest scandal in the history of Australian public administration. The particular document with which we are now confronted seems to me very close to being the biggest snow job in the history of public administration in this country. What was sought in the motion which, of course, has not yet been debated in this place was a specified list of 22 documents or sets of documents relating quite specifically to questions about what the Government knew and what it was advised about as far as the existence and legality of bottom-of-the- harbour schemes were concerned from the early to mid-1970s onwards. Of those 22 documents and sets of documents requested we have been given only eight. We have been refused access to the remaining documents. Of the 14 actual legal opinions and advices that were sought only three have been provided. They are the two relatively innocuous and uninformative but nonetheless still interesting opinions of Messrs Ormiston and Spry at the end of 1978 and the opinion of Mr Arthur Webb in September, I think, of 1978. The contents of those documents already have been the subject of quite well-informed speculation.

We have the extraordinary state of affairs that, as the Minister made clear in the tabling statement, fully 11 opinions or advices that have been sought have not simply been presented to us in a sanitised form; they have been rejected outright as appropriate for this Parliament to look at. That is a matter which I regard as quite unconscionable and quite intolerable. The matter will not be allowed to rest there as far as we are concerned. I make it clear that we members of the Australian Labor Party readily acknowledge the desirability of there not going on the public record any document which conceivably could prejudice a genuine prosecution or legal proceeding. The cursory way in which the Senate's access to these documents is dealt with in the Minister's statement and the criteria that apparently have been applied by the Solicitor-General in advising the Government not to release these documents do not appear to be confined to considerations of that kind. That clearly is a matter that we will have to debate later in this place.

As an illustration of the kinds of documents which have not been made available to us, I shall list those which were mentioned in the original motion but were not given to us: The Brinsden opinion of 1974; the second Brinsden opinion dated June 1975; the series of memoranda as such from Messrs Gleedman, O'Sullivan and Massie of the Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office from 1975 onwards; the opinion of the unnamed Sydney Queen's Counsel on the Norfolk Island matter early in 1976, which bore closely upon the power of the Commonwealth to act in relation to conspiracy and matters of this kind; the police report in the Perth matter; and the Lockhart opinion. None of these matters has been provided to us in the massive documentation that nonetheless now sits on our desk.

Counsel's advice, given in April 1976 on a matter which in fact, on the statement of Mr Howard of 27 June, may have been negative and as such may have done something to round out our perception of this, has not been supplied either . The advices that apparently flowed from the Perth Crown Solicitor's Office to the Sydney Crown Solicitor's Office in the 1977 matter and which were followed, if television reports are accurate, by dissenting memoranda from the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney are not here supplied. The Crown Solicitor's advice-that crucial letter of April 1979 which is referred to in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Costigan report , and is quite central to the credibility of the Government's case-is not provided. The Solicitor-General's advice of June-July 1982, the most recent advice as to the availability of legal action under the existing law against these vendors, promoters and purchasers, is not made available either in any form.

As I indicated all the way along-I have said it again this afternoon-we did not mind these documents being produced in some sanitised form with names of individuals removed from them. The only conclusions to which we can possibly be led in that respect is that the Government has something to hide. That is the very information we need to be able to attribute responsibility in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The initial suggestions that the Government was going to apply some Freedom of Information Act criteria of a much broader brush kind in dealing with this, were said to be not the case and that the Government would in fact be endeavouring to be as full and frank as possible. SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer simply to one such matter, and that is a letter to the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) from the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly, dated 7 November 1979 , which is something of a cry of pain about the Government's inaction on the legislative front, and the Government's manifest incapacity, it appears to Mr O' Reilly at this stage, to get its act together on actually drafting legislation to deal with this phenomenon of straw companies, or what have subsequently become known as bottom-of-the-harbour companies. If I may quote a few paragraphs from Mr O'Reilly's letter of 7 November 1979 I think the point I am making will speak for itself. It states:

I am gravely concerned to hear that there may be some question about going ahead with the planned legislation on this matter, the nature and level of penalties proposed being, I understand, a source of difficulty for some of your colleagues. May I make these points:
There is then a series of dotted points-
These activities are criminal in a nature and fraudulent-they are not merely an aspect of tax avoidance.
The potential of the practices, if left unchecked, is such that legislative action against tax avoidance (including revision of section 260) could be largely to no avail.

This activity is occuring on a large scale, daily. Although the full revenue implications are hard to estimate (because the parties fail to lodge returns and frustrate inquiries), I am having to write off large amounts of assessed income tax because companies have been stripped of assets.

One promoter has stripped over 1,150 companies in Victoria which had income tax liabilities in the year prior to the strip totalling $14m (23 being over $100, 000). When we have matters of that kind some really very interesting questions arise. This was in November 1979, almost 18 months after the Government, on Mr Howard's own acknowledgment, had had drawn to its attention the general nature of these schemes and had directed that some remedial action take place. It was one full year before the 1980 Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill was enacted. Mr President, I present the Commonwealth Electoral (Amendment) Bill 1982.
Mr President, the process of electoral reform in Australia has been a long and tortuous one; almost a microcosm of the whole process of constitutional change which it has parallelled.
As Professor R. S. Parker put it in his Meredith Memorial Lecture in 1979:

'On the first day of this century the governments of the six Australian colonies, after a decade of dickering and bickering, rather reluctantly united for a very limited range of purposes: to form a customs union, to secure an integrated defence system and to speak with a single voice in the comity of nations . . .

'But they wanted to conserve as far as possible the interests of their own regions and of the administrative apparatus they had built up in each colony. So they opted for a federal union, drove a hard bargain about the financial and other terms on which they united, and carefully entrenched them in the written constitution. They did not put in any frills and flourishes about inalienable human rights, codes of conduct for the rulers, or states of national emergency.
It was a modest document of thirty pages-little more than a contract framed to safeguard the federal compact.''

Of the 36 proposals for change generated since Federation, eight have been accepted. Of these, two related to electoral matters. The first ever, in 1906, provided for Senators' terms of office to begin in July instead of the January following their election. The second was one of three passed in 1977, which required casual vacancies in the Senate to be filled by a person from the same party as the vacating Senator, when circumstances allowed.

Proposals for change have not been lacking. The Royal Commission on the Constitution appointed by the Bruce-Page Government in 1927 produced an enormous report in 1929 and made 28 specific recommendations for constitutional amendment . The only ones any government has even attempted to carry out in the half century since were a recommendation that Senators be elected by proportional representation (enacted by ordinary legislation in 1948) and a proposal for a retiring age for High Court Judges (inserted in the Constitution by referendum in 1977).

Early in 1958 the Parliament appointed a Joint Committee on Constitutional Review representing all parties in both Houses. Before the end of 1959 it produced an almost equally massive report. Four of its recommendations with modifications were put to referendums in the 1960s and 1970s. One proposed to break the nexus between the size of the House and that of the Senate so that the House could be expanded without increasing the size of the Senate. The second would have altered Senators' terms from the present six years to correspond with two actual terms of the House of Representatives so that elections for the two houses could always be held simultaneously. The third proposed to equalise federal electoral divisions as nearly as possible in all States. The Fourth would have made constitutional amendment itself easier. None of these proposals secured the necessary approvals at the referendums.

The third major review of the constitution, and particularly the laws regarding elections, was or is the Australian Constitutional Convention initiated by Victorian politicians at the beginning of the 1970s. Honourable Senators will be aware of the painful progress made by the Convention. The Australian Democrats certainly hope it will continue to make progress, although hopefully at a faster rate.

There have also been a number of legislative changes to the electoral law. The Representation Act of 1948 increased the size of the Senate and changed the method by which it was elected. The Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973 made provision for two Senators to be elected from both territories. Several amendments have also been made to the Electoral Act 1918 at various times and redistributions of electoral boundaries are also enacted.

Many Senators present today will recall the events of 1974 when the Labor administration of Mr Whitlam introduced a package of electoral reform bills. Some of the proposals in these Bills were not acceptable to the then Opposition and the Bills were blocked.

This bill takes the whole process, almost completely stymied since those turbulent days, two small steps forward. It provides for the political affiliation of candidates at Parliamentary elections to be printed on ballot papers and to provide for the rotation of names on ballot papers for House of Representatives elections.

The first of these hardly needs debate. Once upon a time some may have opposed it, perhaps hoping people would be confused, or that small parties would be disadvantaged because of the need to print how to vote cards. But I find it difficult to imagine that any enlightened senators could oppose this modest proposal in the 1980s.

The second proposal in this Bill is designed to neutralise the effect of the donkey vote. Again I find it difficult to believe any sensible person could dispute either the existence or the effect of the donkey vote.

If one takes the votes of minor parties and compares their average support in cases where their candidates have the favoured position with those cases where their candidates do not have the favoured position the former averages are consistently higher than the latter.

Where Senate and House of Representatives elections are held together, comparison of the different levels of support in each election according to respective ballot paper position also suggests the donkey vote can be a major influence on the outcome of elections.

Comparisons of different distributions of preferences according to ballot paper positions can indicate the number of donkey votes cast. Malcolm Mackerras in a 1968 paper and in an earlier monograph suggested that one does not need to be on the top of the ballot paper to benefit from the donkey vote. The prime beneficiary is the major candidate more favourably placed than his major opponent.
The final proof is statistical: if the names of members are randomly distributed then one would expect the distribution to be similar to that in the general population; it is not.

Mackerras cites several examples, the most notorious of which was the 1937 general elections when the famous four As team of Amour, Armstrong, Arthur and Ashley was elected to this Senate. This cynicism led the succeeding Menzies UAP Government to introduce legislation to change the law and replace the alphabetical principle by the lot principle in determining the order of names on ballot papers for both houses. However when it was debated in May 1940 the House of Representatives decided to amend the Bill to retain alphabetical arrangements in its own election.

There can be no doubt of the effect of the donkey vote. In 1964 C. J. Masterman demonstrated how the House of Representatives had become filled up with an unusually high proportion of members with names high in the alphabet.

Today's House of Representatives, which has 125 members is little different from earlier chambers. Based on the Melbourne telephone book 50.2 per cent of the population have names beginning with the letters from A to K, yet in the House of Representatives 62.4 per cent of members have letters in the same range . Conversely while in the general population 49.8 per cent of people have names beginning with letters from L to Z in the House only 37.6 per cent of members have names beginning with those letters.

I am assured that statistically it is most improbable that this would occur if there was no bias in the selection of candidates or in the success of candidates towards those who have names which begin with letters high in the alphabet.

I give notice that as soon as possible I will present another equally modest Bill to further amend the Electoral Act so that not only are the groups of Senatorial candidates selected by lot, but that the groups are also rotated in a similar fashion to that I have proposed in this Bill for the House of Representatives.

For those who are interested in such things the parts of the Bill dealing with the printing of names of parties on ballot papers is largely drawn from the 1974 Bill while the part of the Bill dealing with rotation of names has been drawn from Tasmanian legislation.
I thank all those who have helped or commented on this Bill and commend it to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $A212. 33 million towards the third replenishment of the Asian Development Fund.

Honourable senators will know that since the Asian Development Bank was established in 1966 Australia has been and remains a strong and active supporter of the Bank. We continue to regard it as an efficient and effective organisation for providing aid to developing countries in our own geographic region. The main role of the Bank is to assist the economic development of its developing member countries and to foster economic and social growth and co-operation in the Asian and Pacific regions. It does this by lending funds, promoting investment and providing technical assistance on a scale that bilateral donors could not achieve alone. The Bank has continued to approach its complex development task with flexibility and vigour, especially over recent years during which it has been confronted by the growing resource constraints imposed by the global economic recession.

Since its establishment the Bank has lent about $US10 billion for projects covering all the major sectors of economic development with emphasis on the development of transport, communications, industry and electric power as well as projects for agriculture, education, water supply and urban development. In recent years an increasing proportion of the Bank's lending activities has been devoted to agricultural development and to social development (for example in health, population and water supply projects).

The Bank's lending activities are divided into ordinary and special operations. Ordinary operations are financed on the basis of the Bank's capital resources and its borrowings on the international capital market at commercial or near commercial terms. Special operations involve loans made on highly concessional terms to the Bank's poorest and least developed member countries and are funded from the Asian Development Fund.

Australia played a leading role in the establishment and subsequent growth of the Asian Development Fund which was set up in 1974 and first replenished in 1976. The Fund operates in the Asian and Pacific regions in a similar fashion to the World Bank's soft lending affiliate, the International Development Association. Australia contributed $A97 million or 5.14 per cent to the last replenishment target of $US2.15 billion, to cover concessional lending for the period 1979 to 1982. By the end of this year the Bank will have fully committed the resources from the (second) replenishment.

In July 1981 donor countries commenced negotiations for a third replenishment of the Fund, to provide resources for the period 1983 to 1986. Bank management originally suggested a replenishment target of $US4.1 billion in order to maintain growth in the Fund's annual rate of lending at around 17.5 per cent. Australia supported this target and announced its willingness to maintain its share in the Fund at around 5.14 per cent. However when it became clear that the United States intended to reduce significantly its level of contribution, the target was revised to $US3.2 billion. Agreement and donor commitment were achieved earlier this year on this level which will enable the Fund to maintain the level of its concessional lending over the next four years in real terms.

In order to help meet the agree target and to maintain a position appropriate to our standing in the Bank Australia decided to increase its share in the Fund to approximately 7.2 per cent. This represents about the same funding level as the previous 5.14 per cent share of the original target of $US4.1 billion and is commensurate with our share in the Bank's capital stock.

Australia's decision to increase substantially its share in the Fund proved to be critical at the final donor's meeting in April this year at which the target of $US3.2 billion was reached. The exact level of our contribution to the third replenishment of the Asian Development Fund has been set at $A212.33 million. This amount will not be subject to future adjustments in exchange rates.

In accordance with past practice with respect to similar contributions to the Asian Development Fund and the International Development Association, Australia will make its contribution by lodging non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes cashable on demand as and when funds are actually required for making loan payments. This will limit the impact on the Budget in the next year or so, as cashing of these notes is not expected to begin before 1983-84.

The Asian Development Bank and its Asian Development Fund have a most important role to play in continuing to foster economic and social development in the region of immediate interest to Australia. Our contribution to the third replenishment of the Fund will confirm our willingness to continue helping the poorest developing countries in our region with highly concessional assistance. This Bill amends the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Act 1980 to extend the present arrangement under which a subsidy of $80 a tonne is paid on LPG use by certain consumers for a further twelve months until 28 March 1984. Provisions have also been included in the Bill to impose limitations on the amounts of subsidised gas available to industrial consumers after the first of October this year.
The LPG subsidy was introduced for three years in March 1980 with the objective of providing sufficient time for household users to adjust to rapidly rising LPG prices.

The extension of the subsidy is largely to help the many thousands of householders, small businessmen and other consumers who depend on LPG, to cope through a period of uncertainty in world LPG prices, expected to occur in the next year or two.

On the other hand the Government does not intend that the subsidy encourage new scale industrial use of LPG. This policy was clearly stated in 1980 when the subsidy was made available to industrial and commercial users in areas where natural gas was not readily available.

Over the last two years the competitiveness of LPG as an industrial fuel has created a situation where large industrial consumers with heavy reliance on fuel oil could be encouraged to convert to LPG.
The Government does not wish to encourage such conversion for a number of reasons.
First, the resulting large increase in subsidy payments could not be justified.

Secondly, LPG is a valuable transport fuel and petrochemical feedstock, unconstrained large scale industrial use of the fuel could establish a demand imbalance leading eventually to a reduction in the amount available for traditional and premium applications such as small commercial and household consumers who, by reason of their location, do not have access to suitable alternative forms of energy.
Thirdly, it would be in conflict with the Government's basic policy aim of minimising Australia's dependence on imported liquid fuels.

The considerations that I have just mentioned led the Government to announce on 25 September 1981 its intention to impose limitations on the amount of subsidized gas to which industrial and commercial enterprise would be entitled.

At that time the Government also announced that a review of the subsidy scheme would be made prior to the expiry of the scheme in March 1983. Following that review, which culminated in the decision to extend the subsidy for a further 12 months, the administrative arrangements relating to the imposition of the limitations were finalised.

The limits to be imposed on the usage of subsidized gas as proposed by this Bill, will apply from 1 October 1982. From that date most industrial enterprises will be restricted to the equivalent of 1,000 tonnes per annum of subsidized gas .
The Government does recognise however, that on 25 September 1981 some users were already using or were committed to use LPG in excess of the equivalent of 1 ,000 tonnes per annum.

The Government will not deprive such users of the benefit of the subsidy. For this reason the Bill provides a mechanism to permit the Minister to increase the limit if he is satisfied that certain contracts relating to the purchase of gas or equipment, or conversion of existing plant and equipment to gas, prior to 25 September 1981, would require the equivalent of an annual usage in excess of 1, 000 tonnes per annum.

The Bill also provides for notifications to be given by industrial and commercial users to the distributors from whom they purchase the gas, and to the Minister, when they have exceeded their limit or they are about to reach their limit.

Penalties have been introduced into the legislation ranging from $2,000 to $50, 000 for offences associated with failing to produce documents or failing to notify or knowingly obtaining or attempting to obtain the benefit of a subsidy payment to which the user is not entitled.
The Government will continue to monitor the impact of this subsidy on its energy policy and will conduct a further review prior to the new expiry date of 27 March 1984.

These Bills seek to increase sales tax at the lowest rate from a current 5 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent; at the middle rate from 17 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent; and at the top rate from 30 per cent to 32 1/2 per cent . At the lowest rate it represents a 5 per cent increase over the last two Budgets. When we were discussing the sales tax Bills last year there was a great uproar about them. Tonight we hear that the Opposition has made a cosy arrangement with the Government so that the Government can get the Bills passed through the Senate tonight. Only one speaker from the Opposition has spoken against this particular measure tonight. Of course, we have heard Senator Siddons. Only one speaker is put forward by the Government to defend the increase of 2 1/2 per cent in sales tax contained in these particular Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a far cry from what occurred last year but the principle is the same. The principle is to shift the balance from direct taxes to indirect taxes. The Government is doing this by stealth. It is all very well to say that the necessities of life are not covered in this measure but the sales tax on a number of items is creeping up. For example, the extensions this year will include household drapery, soft furnishings, sheets and towels. Whilst some honourable senators might be able to do away with sheets and those honourable senators who do not wash can do away with towels, I cannot do without them. Honourable senators may be able to get away without curtains in their homes but I live on a fairly busy road and I cannot do without them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you got to hide?
—What about toilet paper? Can you do without that?

—Yes, indeed. One can always use newspapers. They are still free from tax. All jokes aside, this is a very important issue. It amazes me that the Government has not put forward any other speaker, barring the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), to defend the extension of and the increase in sales tax. I would have preferred a White Paper or a Green Paper -one can call it what one likes-being tabled by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the whole question of taxation. We have the report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee. A number of matters contained in that report are worth while considering.
—One of them was this.

—Yes, Senator Messner. It has been suggested that this measure implements some of the recommendations made in the Asprey report-recommendations which have been adopted by the Government. The suggestion has been made that it is necessary to shift the burden from direct taxes to indirect taxes for two major reasons: Firstly, it will spread the burden and, secondly, an indirect broadly based commodity tax will lessen the chances of tax cheating. As to the latter suggestion, one has only to visit some of the industries that are involved in certifications and the requirements for sales tax to see the vast problems involved.

SPEECH.PARA: One needs only to refer to the article in the Australian Financial Review this morning which indicates that there are vast problems of tax evasion in this area . Indeed, official figures available indicate that there is a substantial increase in the number of cases concerning evasion which have been detected in this area. I had the figures a moment ago but I seem to have mislaid them. Nevertheless, when this measure was adopted last year the Senate was in uproar about it. The Bills concerned were returned to the House of Representatives with requests. I, for one, travelled throughout the length and breadth of Australia campaigning against the extension of the sales tax, particularly to those provisions covering the so-called necessities of life. We do not have presented to us for our consideration tonight just how a broadly based commodity tax will operate. Will it operate with progressivity or regressivity? If the latter, how will the Government compensate those people upon whom the tax burden falls most heavily? I suggest to the Minister that if the Government is attempting by stealth to implement a policy which would change the balance of taxation from direct taxes to indirect taxes, let us have all the information before us. Let us have from the Treasurer and from the Minister for Finance a free and open statement detailing the advantages and disadvantages, and where there are disadvantages, detailing how these can be overcome and compensated.

In the absence of a stronger amendment, I propose to support the Opposition's amendment. I would have preferred to have seen a real battle take place on this measure in order at least to hold the legislation up so that we get from the Government some explanation of the reason for the 2 1/2 per cent increase, not on one commodity but on all of them, ranging from 5 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent in the lowest category to 20 per cent in the middle category and to a high 32 1/ 2 per cent in the top category. I should have liked to have seen the Senate hold these measures up until we got from the Government an explanation in support of them and also an explanation of how the Government proposes to compensate those upon whom the burden will fall most heavily. However, it looks as though even if I were to move a motion for the adjournment of the debate on these Bills I would not receive support. I should have thought that the opportunity is quite clearly here now to put the Government on toast on these issues, but there is no will left in the Opposition to do this. I can only express my amazement at that and hope that--

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- These Bills give effect to the Budget proposals with regard to changes in sales tax. I do not propose to delay their passage through the Senate. A number of comments have been made expressing various views and personal attitudes but the purpose of the Bills is clear. They are required as part of the Budget revenue raising proposals. SPEECH.PARA: Some concern has been expressed that master originals of motion picture films may be taxed at their full cost of production. When films were previously taxable, master originals were taxed on the basis of a value per foot of film. The values were quite low, being 16c per foot for 16mm entertainment films and 7c per foot for 35mm entertainment films. The result was that the tax payable on master original films reflected the cost of making the actual film but not the cost of producing it. The previous policy will be followed on 1 January 1983 when films become taxable. Where master originals are subject to tax, they will be taxed at a sale value based on the length of the film. Of course, the previous values will need to be reviewed by the Commissioner of Taxation. They will produce an effect similar to that which existed before 1967 in respect of master originals; that is, the tax payable will be charged on a much lower value than the actual cost of production. I make that explanation because representations concerning the matter were made during the passage of the Bills. I now commend the Bills to the Senate.
