DEBATE.TITLE: AIR NAVIGATION LEGISLATION (VALIDATION AND INTERPRETATION) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly in relation to the Air Navigation Legislation (Validation and Interpretation) Bill 1982 because the question of air navigation charges is a very important one which has concerned the whole cost structure of the air transport industry for a considerable time. Whilst I am not familiar with the details of this Bill, which has been called on at somewhat short notice, I appreciate the very grave concern which is felt by the airline industry due to the proposed increases in air navigation charges which are apparent in this legislation.
—They have been lowered.

—No, not in real terms, Senator. My colleague Senator Gietzelt will be dealing with that question in some detail when he speaks in a moment. The point I simply seek to make is that this whole issue of air navigation charges has bedevilled the air transport industry in Australia for a very long time.
—Senator, could you make your remarks relevant to the Bill before the chamber?

—With the greatest respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would have thought that nothing I have said so far was not relevant to the Bill. I feel very offended by what has been put to me and I will not continue my contribution to this debate at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Air Navigation Legislation (Validation and Interpretation) Bill 1982. It is a fairly simple Bill which highlights the complete incompetence of the Fraser Administration. We have wasted well over an hour this evening ostensibly because of the importance of government business. This piece of legislation arose out of the complete incompetence of the Fraser Government when it brought about ministerial changes a short time ago. It is purely a machinery measure to correct an error that occurred when the Department of Transport was needlessly and unnecessarily, in our view, split into two separate departments-one of transport and construction and the other of aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague in the other place, Mr Morris, pointed out, if the Government was aware of its responsibilities, was competent, knew what it was doing and knew in which direction it was heading, there would have been no need for this special piece of legislation, which is one of the reasons why the Senate tonight was denied an opportunity, on a broadcast day, to debate the very important deficiences that exist in the Department of Primary Industry, as expressed in Mr Justice Woodward's report on the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry.

The Opposition takes the view that the splitting of the Department of Transport , which has led to the necessity for this Bill, represents a retrograde step on the part of the Government. It represents an artificial and inefficient division of the administration of transport in this country. It will undoubtedly encourage disorganisation and an absence of planning and co-ordination. In recent weeks we have witnessed further proof of the inept and deficient government of this country. That is apparent whether we talk about tax evasion, Medibank fraud or the activities of the Department of Primary Industry in relation to Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd or the meat inspection service . No matter which part of government administration we examine-for example, the administration of the Australian Federal Police-we find that there is constant change in administration at the hands of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. There is a constant change of Ministers and ministerial arrangements and the transference of departments here, there and everywhere. For example, Estimates Committee C, in considering the appropriations for the Department of Administrative Services found that, as a result of the recent ministerial rearrangements, it had been obliged to absorb such organisations as the Industries Assistance Commission and the Trade Practices Commission, which hitherto had been part of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. If there are weaknesses in public administration-as has been suggested by the Prime Minister in seeking a scapegoat for deficiencies in ministerial responsibility-the Prime Minister has contributed materially to that maladministration by his constant changing of Ministers and, in consequence, of ministerial responsibility.

The Opposition is concerned about the necessity for this Bill and deplores the circumstances that led to its introduction. We also deplore that tonight the Government Whip sought to mislead the Senate and suggested that there had been a breakdown on our part in regard to the way in which the Senate should operate when, clearly, it had been indicated by the Government that this was a vital and important piece of legislation. Only one other measure remains to be dealt with. Neither is important in regard to the Budget or in regard to their becoming effective before some date in October. Both could have been dealt with expeditiously without any problems at all. But, of course, the Government has set out on a course of denying the Opposition an opportunity to debate Mr Justice Woodward's very critical and awkward report concerning the operations of the Department of Primary Industry and the role of its Minister, Mr Nixon, against which the Government found that it had to defend itself yesterday in the House of Representatives.

One would have expected that the Government, having decided upon the retrograde step of splitting the ministry of transport into two ministries, would have been able to carry out the simple procedures necessary to facilitate the transfer of powers and of delegation from the Secretary to the Department of Transport to the Secretary to the new Department of Aviation. That simple administrative step could have been taken when the division was made but the Government, in its haste and incompetence, failed to take that essential step, one so minor in terms of proper public administration. This reveals again that the Fraser Government cannot be relied upon to carry out even the simplest administrative practices within the Department of Aviation and the Department of Transport and Construction. The Opposition concedes that within those departments there are very highly skilled officers, of dedication and competence, who give of their best in service to the people and government of this country. I must express sympathy for them in endeavouring to cope with the resources made available to them. by this Government, and the lack of leadership that is given them as a result of the constant changes of Minister and of ministerial arrangements. In my view, those officers cannot be blamed.

This is but another example of complete incompetence on the part of this Government's Ministers-incompetence such as we find when we consider Mr Justice Woodward's Royal Commission report, such as we found in respect of Medibank fraud under two previous Ministers for Health, and such as we found in respect of the administration by the former Minister for Primary Industry in respect of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd-but most of all, incompetence such as we found in respect of the administration of the tax laws of this country. I have in mind the grave deficiencies in the way in which the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have carried out their duties. We have to consider the lamentable fact that the Treasurer only 24 hours after his return to this country had the audacity to suggest that there were deficiencies within the Australian Taxation Office and to attempt to shift the blame from himself to the Public Service.

Yesterday we had the spectacle of the Prime Minister proposing that there should now be a public inquiry into the Public Service, one gathers at the senior level-suggesting that all of the deficiencies that exist are to be found within the Public Service rather than within the Government itself. This lack of competence on the part of the Prime Minister and his Ministers is clearly indicated in the legislation that is before the Senate. It may not provide an example that is of the order of the scandals that we have been discussing.

I suppose we are indebted to Senator Lewis for indicating the amount of time that the Senate has spent in the more than five weeks of the Budget session so far, in considering such matters. It is true that the Senate has spent a great deal of time in discussing matters of public importance and matters associated with incompetence and Government corruption. But that is the role of a parliament. It is not something to be denigrated or criticised. That is what we are here to do. In 1973 to 1975 it was claimed that the Senate had the God-given right to play the role of a House of review, yet it is now suggested that there is something improper in using the forms of the House to debate inefficiencies in government administration. The Australian people now know of the continuous decline in public administration under this Government.

Although this Bill cannot be placed in the category of the other scandals that the Parliament has discussed in recent weeks, it too indicates yet again the gross incompetence of the Prime Minister and his Ministers in making these ministerial arrangements. It merely adds to the volume of evidence of the Fraser Government's maladministration, incompetence and inability to pursue any proper form of public administration-a task which in 1975, 1977 and 1980 it was elected to perform. This matter, which should have been the subject of a simple administrative act, has had the Department in a state of confusion in the 16 weeks since the new arrangements were made. It has taken the Government all of that time to prepare a technically simple little machinery Bill. Yet the Minister had the gall tonight to say that these were matters of major importance . If they were matters of major importance, why did the Government not present them on the first sitting day of this session? The Government knows that there is very little legislation in the first few days of sittings. This Bill has only one or two lines for consideration by the Senate and yet it has taken into the sixth week of the session for it to come to the Senate for consideration.

Let us not have any more of this humbug that somehow or other it is the Opposition that is frustrating the affairs of the Government or the way in which the Senate is operating. The Bill is a piece of paper that contains 20 or 30 lines. That is the legislation with which the Government denied the Senate the opportunity to debate the report of Mr Justice Woodward on meat inspection. The Government has done that so it can deal with this simple Bill and the next Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation but it expresses its disgust at the way in which the Government is operating in the Senate.

LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 to increase the maximum rates of levy which may be prescribed to finance the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, meat and livestock research and cattle disease eradication. Concurrently, I will be introducing a bill for parallel amendments to the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977.

The two Acts to be amended raise funds from the meat and livestock Industry for the same purposes and are similar in structure and rates, but one applies to livestock slaughtered and the other to stock exported live.

The proposed increases covered by this Bill have been recommended to me by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation after consultation with industry groups. The Government accepts that the Corporation will need an increase in levy income in order to avoid operating at a deficit or cutting back on its activities and service to the industry and that this will first necessitate an increase in the maximum rates currently provided in the legislation.

The levy is imposed on slaughterings of cattle, calves, bobby calves, sheep, lambs, buffaloes and goats. It has separate components for the financing of the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation, meat and livestock research, meat processing research and cattle disease eradicaton. There are comparable rates for each component in respect of each class of livestock.

The Act specifies maximum rates only with operative rates being prescribed by regulation. Separate maximum rates already exist in the Legislation for the research and disease eradication components. In addition, the operative rates set for the research and AMLC components must not exceed a specified maximum. Hence, the highest level of AMLC component is limited by the level of the prevailing research components. Currently, this difference is insufficient to enable the AMLC component to be increased to the level considered necessary.
It is therefore proposed to double the aggregate maximum rates which govern the size of the AMLC component.
The existing and proposed levy rates are:
Maximum rates (c/Head)
current proposed
Cattle and Buffaloes 150.0 300.0 Bobby Calves (40 kg and less) 15.0 30.0 Calves (40 kg and up to 90 kg) 52.5 105.0 Sheep, Lambs and Goats 15.0 30.0
The effect of the proposed changes is to enlarge the scope available for increasing the AMLC component while preserving the existing relativity with the research components.

I now turn to the changes proposed for the cattle disease eradication component which were announced in the Budget. This levy applies only to bovine animals. The current rates are at the maximum level permitted by the Act.

Finance for the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign has been falling behind costs. While the Government has announced in the Budget that it will write-off the outstanding industry debt of $23.5 million, it is anxious to ensure that the continuing program does not result in the industry building up a further debt. This Bill is therefore providing for an increase in the current maximum rates by two-thirds-from $3 to $5 for cattle and buffaloes, $1 to $1.67 for calves, and 30 cents to 50 cents for bobby calves.

It is not, however, intended that the disease eradication component be immediately set at these new levels. As stated in the Budget, the operative rate , with effect from October 1, 1982, will be raised from $3 to $4 per head for cattle, with corresponding increases for other classes of livestock.

This increase follows a thorough review of the eradication campaign and its financing, and must be seen in the context of the package of assistance offered in the Budget to the cattle and meat industry.
In addition to these amendments opportunity is being taken to bring references in the Act to the Meat Exporter and Abattoir Consultative Group into conformity with the changed title of that group.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
LIVE-STOCK EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENTS BILL 1982

This Bill is a companion measure to the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill just introduced. It proposes similar amendments to the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977. These were explained in my second reading speech on the earlier measure.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may paraphrase what my colleague Senator Button once said in similar circumstances, the Opposition does not oppose the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill or the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill. If anyone wants to know the reason, I suggest he consult the House of Representatives Hansard to read Mr Kerin's speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill seeks to raise the maximum rate of slaughter levy from $3 to $5. If one looks at this Bill one will see that yet again the meat industry has been taken for a ride. I refer in particular to the type of suggestions that the Government has been putting, and indeed has put to me in answer to a question I asked in relation to this matter. The Government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The funds raised through the previous $3 per head levy have not kept pace with the actual operating costs of the campaign.

That is a complete fabrication. To show that that is the case I refer the Senate to the old levy charge of $1 per head. At 30 June 1979 industry debt was just over $18m. At that time the levy was $1 per head. The following day the levy rose to $3 a head. In the 1979-80 financial year-that is the first year in which the levy was $3-the levy collected from the industry exceeded the Commonwealth's expenditure by $150,000. However that year the Commonwealth opted for the first time to levy interest charges on that debt. At that time the interest charges were $1,973,000. That raised the total industry debt to nearly $20m. Note that at that time the industry was more than paying its way with $3 a head.

In the financial year 1980-81 the levy raised $1,595,000. So the amount of slaughter levy raised was more than the expenditure by the Commonwealth under the Act. Again the Commonwealth charges had risen in line with the rising amount of debt. Interest payments were then $2.5m. So the actions of this Government, regardless of what the industry paid, were putting an increasing burden on the industry. At the end of the 1981-82 financial year the industry had a debt of $ 23.5m. However during 1982 the industry, again at $3 a head, contributed more than the cost of the campaign, more than the Commonwealth's expenditure. This is where the fiddle has taken place and where the meat industry and the cattle producers have been sold down the drain yet again.

In the Budget the Government, with largesse, said that it would waive the $23. 5m debt. But it continued to make the claim, as I stated a moment ago, that the funds raised through the previous $3 a head levy had not kept pace with the actual operating costs of the campaign. On the figures from the Bureau of Animal Health that is false. The information supplied to the Senate by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is false. The levy has kept pace with the campaign ever since it was set at $3 a head; that is, ever since 1 July 1979. So the reason given for the introduction of this Bill is entirely spurious.

The levy is now to be increased from $3 to $4 a head for particular animals-not all. It is to apply to cattle as of 1 October 1982 but not to calves or poddy calves, which since 1 July 1979 have had a differentiated rate. But as of 1 October 1982 the levy on cattle slaughter, which is generally the bench-mark on which the slaughter levy is set, is to rise to $4 a head with a maximum of $5. In other words, the cattle producers are now being asked to cop an increase in the slaughter levy despite the fact that they have paid more than the operating costs of the campaign. This is in complete contradiction to the Government's propaganda. But based on the figures which have been supplied by the Bureau of Animal Health, the producers will have to pay more of the debt. The Government in its Budget said: 'We are now wiping out a debt of $23.5m. This is our handout .' Yet the vast bulk of that debt was accruing through interest rates charged by the Commonwealth because the Commonwealth had failed dismally in its brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign.

The intent, under this legislation, is to create a further impost on the cattle industry at a time when it can ill afford it and to increase the levy charged when indeed the governments of comparable countries such as Canada, the United States and New Zealand bear entirely the costs of these eradication campaigns. This Government has introduced a Bill to increase the impost at a time when the cattle industry can ill afford it; thereby it is going backwards in its own contributions to these campaigns. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the Cattle Council of Australia, the Cattlemen's Union and other cattle organisations have not been hoodwinked by the Government. This fact is witnessed by the Press releases relating to this matter. If the Minister would like to go out into the cattle producing country and talk to the producers who are in such dire difficulties he will find that they are not hoodwinked by the type of propaganda that the Government has put about concerning the slaughter levy. They will realise that they have been taken for a ride yet again and that they have contributed more than the operating costs of the campaign ever since 1 July 1979 when the slaughter levy was raised to $3. I hope the Minister will be able to explain why the Government has seen fit to give to me and to other honourable senators the type of information which is contrary to the figures that have been produced by the Bureau of Animal Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation. I point out that the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1982 and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1982 were announced in the Budget to commence from 1 October 1982. In the event of that not occurring there will be a loss of revenue to the Government which is incorporated in its Budget figuring. I, therefore, had hoped that we would have unanimous support for this legislation as it represents a Budget measure on which the Government relies. For that reason I implore honourable senators on all sides of the chamber to support this legislation. I wish it a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate unduly but tonight I wish to submit a request to Senator Baume, the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh), regarding the bicentennial celebrations. I do so in relation to a virtually forgotten Prime Minister of Australia, John Christian Watson. He was unique among our Prime Ministers. He did not have a very long period in politics and he led only a short term minority government. Among other things, his parents were of Scottish ancestry and he was born in Valparaiso in Chile.

SPEECH.PARA: As recently as last Friday, I attended a function at the Chilean Sporting and Social Club at Punchbowl. The club operates in the Earlwood region. It was significant that the 16-year-old son of the club president, Mr Frank Martin, said to me very directly: 'At a time when Australia is becoming more historically conscious, at least it had one Prime Minister who had Latin American links'. He did. I feel that the time is opportune for Senator Baume to take on board consideration of some form of memorial or monument in Sydney for John Watson. If my colleague, Senator Childs were here, he would say 'amen' because Watson was a compositor and one of the early members of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union. At 24 years of age he held the leading position of President of the Trades and Labour Council in Sydney. In fact, he was Prime Minister at 37 and at 43 he drifted out of politics. I used that word 'drifted' advisedly. He had differences with his party at the time of the conscription battle, but I think that when people differ with their party there is a certain point at which they stop without necessarily joining their political enemies.

John Watson had a very substantial career in Sydney commercial circles between the two wars. He was one of the leading people in the National Roads and Motorists Assocation for a long time in New South Wales. I simply say that at a time when we are boasting about our cosmopolitan content in the community at large, it would be a nice gesture if this suggestion that emanated from a relatively small fledgling Latin American club, the Chilean Sporting and Social Club, could be taken on board by Senator Baume and given to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that there have been reports of incidents occurring in the United States where school children have been able to break the coded password security systems of computers in that country. I am advised however the the computers involved are connected to public data communications utilities to which anyone owning a computer can pay a fee and connect their own computer.
(2) The computers owned by my Department are stand-alone units and I am advised that they cannot be accessed in the manner that has occurred in the United States.

My Department also uses the CSIRONET computer network. I am advised that CSIRO has complex and thorough security systems in place to prevent unauthorised access to the network and its data and it is extremely unlikely that feats similar to those achieved by the American school children would be possible.
(3) Security precautions for computers owned by the Department include:
the computers are not connected to public data transmission facilities
hardware is located in secure areas
coded passwords are required to access data on the computers
knowledge of the passwords is restricted to authorised Departmental officers.
Security precautions for the CSIRONET computer network also used by the Department include:
hardware is located in secure areas
coded passwords are required to gain access to CSIRONET and further passwords are required to access data
knowledge of the passwords is restricted to authorised Departmental officers.

(4) I am aware of the need to ensure that confidential data maintained on computer files is accorded the necessary degree of protection against unauthorised access. I am assured that no 'grave security risks' exist in my Department's computer systems.

(5) The honourable senator will be aware that it is not possible to give an unequivocal assurance that data held on Departmental computer files cannot be accessed by unauthorised means. However I can assure the honourable senator that my Department has taken all practicable precautions to prevent such unauthorised access occurring.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's Department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of media reports on this problem.
(2) It is highly unlikely that unauthorised access could be gained to information stored in computers used by my Department and Statutory Authorities within my portfolio.

(3) The CSIRO Division of Computer Research operates a computer network called CSIRONET which is used by many Commonwealth Departments and Authorities in addition to CSIRO and the Department of Science and Technology.

Access to CSIRONET is limited to registered users who are able to identify themselves by providing a unique user identification code linked to a valid project code. User identification codes are further protected by a mandatory user password. The project identification code can also be password protected. These passwords are easily changed to minimise the risk of accidental security breaches.

Access to CSIRONET does not automatically give access to data held by the system. Password protection is available for all files by the CSIRONET on behalf of users. In addition, some systems restrict file access to a nominated list of users while others offer data encryption facilities.

CSIRONET security facilities rely on a mix of mandatory and elective features. The mandatory features are rigidly enforced. The elective features are available , but it is a matter for users to determine whether or not the nature of their business warrants this high level of protection.

Access to computer records within the Department of Science and Technology is similarly restricted. Apart from physical security, a series of user codes and changing passwords must be used before access can be gained to computer records.

(4) See answer to (2) above. However, even the remote chance of unauthorised access to computer records, whether it constitutes a security risk or invasion of privacy, is of concern to the Government. The Australian Law Reform Commission has before it a reference to examine and report on invasions of privacy arising from matters under the control of the Commonwealth Parliament.
(5) While it is not possible to give an absolute assurance, the strictest security measures have been taken to prevent unauthorised access to computer systems in my portfolio.
